title: aldi-bring-back-christmas-favourite-brits-prepare-celebrate-junemas
story: Aldi is bringing back its famous Christmas mince pies to help Brits celebrate lsquoJunemasrsquo.As anticipation builds for lockdown restrictions lting completely on June , Brits are gearing up to enjoy the Christmas we never had on June .With limited celebrations in December amid coronavirus lockdown restrictions, research has shown that nearly half of Britsare planning to celebrate lsquoJunemasrsquo with friends and family next month.And to help Brits celebrate the festivities, Aldi is bringing back its popular Specially Selected Mini Mince Pies." alt"Border : Specially Selected Mini Mince Pies. " class"editor-image"Specially Selected Mini Mince Pies. When asked what festive food they would most like to see back on shelves this Junemas, nearly half of Britslisted mince pies as their quintessential Christmas treat.Web searches for lsquomince piesrsquo also went up by an incredible  per centin April alone, as the nation prepares to celebrate Christmas this summer.With  per centof people planning a lockdown-lting party, the most popular celebration is set to be with our closest friends, with over  per centof those polled looking forward to being reunited with pals theyrsquove missed, closely followed by get-togethers with extended family .Julie Ashfield, managing director of buying at Aldi, said: ldquoThe first Friday post-lockdown will feel like Christmas, as we all get to meet up with friends and family after months apart.ldquoWe thought letrsquos make it a Junemas to remember by bringing back the nations festive favourite - mince pies - to help celebrate this very special occasion.Aldirsquos Specially Selected Mini Mince Pies will be available for pound. in-store nationwide from June .Follow Aldi as it gears up for the summer celebrations on #AldiJunemaswhere shoppers can cast their vote on what other yuletide favourites they would like to see back in store for Junemas.

title: melrose-meeting-hears-dog-broke-leg-bridge-near-newstead
story: A DOG broke its leg on wooden decking near a Borders town, a meeting has heard.The pet was injured between Melrose and Newstead while on a walk.The incident was discussed at Melrose Community Council on Wednesday, April .Robin Chisholm said: ldquoTherersquos a raised walkway with a wooden decking. Someone was walking their dog and one of its legs got stuck and it broke its leg.Jenny Linehan, a Scottish Borders Council member for Melrose, said: ldquoI know exactly what you mean and I have to carry my dog over it.Ms Linehan, of the Conservatives, said that rabbit or chicken fencing on the walkway might solve the issue.You might also be interested in:Borders nightclub boss on venues futureafter plans suggest flats to be createdSmashed window at Borders golf club prompts appealover suspicious activityThe ambitious Borders residentswho want to buy their local village green

title: regional-list-vote-counted
story: AS Scotland heads to the polls today it is important to understand how both of your votes are counted.Every voter has two votesto elect candidates to the Scottish Parliament ndashthe constituency vote and the regional list vote.The constituency vote takes the form of a lilac coloured ballot and is where you vote for inidual politicians to represent your constituency. There are  constituencies in Scotland.The constituency vote is run on a first past the post system, which means whichever candidate wins the most votes in that constituency is elected to represent it in parliament. This system is used in General Elections for Westminster.The regional list vote will take the form of a peach coloured ballot andis more complicated to understand how your vote will count.How many regions are there in Scotland There are eight regions in Scotland that eachseven MSPs. This means there are a total of  list MSPs in the Scottish Parliament.Theregions are:Central ScotlandGlasgowHighlands and IslandsLothianMid Scotland and FeNorth East ScotlandSouth ScotlandWest ScotlandEach region has between eight and  constituencies within it. Regardless of which constituency you are in, your peach ballot goes into the regional list vote pool.Each party will also have a ranked list of candidates for each region so as well as looking at who your constituency candidates are, its also a good idea to look at who is on your chosen partys regional list.What is the dHondt method and how does it work at this election The dHondt system of voting is a form of proportional representation that aims to ensureall voters are represented fairly.The system is named after Belgian mathematician Victor dHondt who first described the methodology in .First, all the peach ballots for the region are counted and the total number of ballots is ided by the number of seats each party has already won from that regions constituencies plus one.So, letrsquos say Party A wins all nine constituencies in Glasgow and also get , peach ballots in that region.Their total number of peach ballots is then ided by the number of seats already won plus one. , peach votes ided by   , votes.Letrsquos say Party B and Party Chave won , and , peach ballots from Glasgow respectively. As Party Ahave won every constituency seat, they are both currently on zero.As such, we need to ide their total number of votes by their seats wonplus one. So, , ided by one  ,, and , ided by one  ,.As Party B have the most votes of these three parties, they would win a list seat. The candidate elected would be taken from the top of the Party B list for this region.Now, the process is repeated. However, this time Party B have one seat.So, Party Asvote remains the same . Party C also remains the same , but Party Bs has changed.Their one seat means that their , list votes are now ided by one seat plus one. So, , ided by two  ,.Party C now have the most votes , so they win a list seat.Party Cs vote would then drop to , and the process is repeated five more times to complete the seven regional members elected to the Scottish Parliament.Along with the winners from each constituency, this means that each Scot is represented by eight MSPs.

title: elections-2021-cant-polling-station
story: Scotswill today cast their vote in the most important Holyrood election yet on what has been dubbed "Super Thursday"A record number of people have already cast their ballots - with more than a million having registered to vote by post in Scotland.However, millions will stillheadto vote for their preferred party as the polling stations willstay open until pm on Thursday but undernew Covid guidelines.Many rules and regulations are already in place for when you go to vote so we have outlined what you need to know.Heres what you can and cannot do at the polling stationHow do I find my polling station If you have registered tovote you should have received a polling card in the post.This card will have yourpolling number and the address for where you cast your vote - your polling station.Alternatively, you can check here.To vote, you have to turn up at the polling station between : and : today.Do I need to bring my polling card No, youdo not have to bring your polling card when you vote.However, this can speed up the process when you are there.WhatI have not receivedmy card If your card has not turned up and you do not know where your polling station is, you can contact your local authoritys election office.Will polling stations be Covid safe Yes, polling stations will be Covid safe.There will be extra signs, plastic screens, one-way systems, and hand sanitiser in place.Do I need to wear a face-covering Yes, everyone is asked to wear a face-covering inside the polling station.However, the Electoral Commission says no-one will be turned awaythey refuse to wear one.WhatI cannot turn up on the day It is too late to apply for a postal vote.However, you can still apply for an emergency proxy voteyou meet certain conditions.Can I sign my ballot paper Yes butyour name is identiable,the vote will not count.Can I tell my social media followers how I voted Yes but you cannot take a picture of the ballot paper or you could get afine of up to pound,, or six months in prison.Should I bring my own pen or pencil Voters are asked to bring their own pen or pencil, to keep the process as hygienic as possible.But some pencils should be available in the polling station, for those who forget.Are pets allowed No.Animals, apart from assistance dogs, are not usually allowed in polling stations.Can I wear political clothing Yes, but campaigning inside polling stations is not permitted.Can I voteIve been drinking Yes as long as you are notdisruptive.Can I take a selfie The Electoral Commission advises against this because it risks accidentally giving away how someone  voted.But people are welcome to share photos taken outside a polling station "to encourage your friends and family to vote".Can I discuss the candidates No. Political discussion is banned inside polling stations.Staff will intervenethey hear any chat about candidates or parties.Can my children come Bringing children to the polling station is encouraged, because it is seen as educating them about democracy.But a child is not allowed to mark your vote on the ballot paper.Can I spoil my ballot paper Some people deliberately spoil their vote - for example, by writing a message on the ballot paper as a protest.These are recorded but do not count for or against any candidate.Is voting compulsory No - it is entirely up to you whether or not you vote.Who counts the votes Local councils recruit the presiding officer and staff to conduct the ballot, count the votes and process the postal votes.When will I know who won the election The first councils will be counted overnight into early Friday morning.But making the process Covid-secure means the results will probably take much longer than usual - possibly as late as Monday in some areas.Can I have helpI am disabled The presiding officer can mark the paper for you, or a close adult family member or another eligible voter, such as a support worker, can accompany you.People with a visual impairment can request a device that lets them mark their own ballot paper. A large-print version should also be available.Polling stations are selected for accessibility. Buta voter cannot enter, the presiding officer may take the ballot paper to them.For help, call the Electoral Commission on   .

title: lockdown-easing-borders-pubs-hotels-happy-open
story: HOSPITALITY venues across the Borders reopened last week after Scotland was moved down to Level  of coronavirus restrictions.Since last Monday , pubs, restaurants and cafeacutes have been allowed to serve alcohol in outdoor settings, while food and non-alcoholic drinks are permitted inside.In outdoor settings, six people from six households can meet with a closing time of pm, while six people from two households are able to meet at indoor venues which have to close at pm.Rob Chisholm, manager of the Ship Inn in Melrose, said: ldquoItrsquos been brilliant welcoming back all our friendly faces. Wersquore a big part of the community here in Melrose.ldquoIt can really help peoplersquos mental health. For some of the older residents we might be [the only] people they see in a day.ldquoItrsquos been phenomenal, you know, to get that face to face connection for that social element. Wersquove been so fortunate, wersquove got a booking system and the response has been phenomenal.ldquoItrsquos trying to accommodate everyone which can be the tricky part but wersquove been overwhelmed with the response.:Dog broke its leg during walk on popular route in the Borders, meeting hearsAndrew Hittle, owner of the Neidpath Inn in Peebles, said he was ldquodefinitely happy to be able to reopen the doors but the weather put a dampener on the occasion for some.ldquoThere was a very good turnout other than Tuesdaywhen the weather was quite bad, he said. ldquoThe majority were excited to be back, a small amount of people were a touch upset about being outside.Mr Hittle said the Neidpath has ldquoimprovised quite well in the beer garden with table heaters, fire pits and a TV in the window among the features available.:Borders nightclub boss on venues future after plans suggest flats to be createdApril  also saw the reopening of tourism accommodation, coinciding with the relaxation of travel rules so people can now go anywhere across Scotland, England and Wales.James Henderson, manager of the Townhouse Hotel in Melrose, said: ldquoIt is great to get back open again. It has been a pretty steady week and we now have residents back into the hotel. We have had a mixture of people visit ndash local people and people from south of the border, which is great.ldquoWe are very lucky we have indoor and outdoor facilities however, it would be niceit was a bit warmer.ldquoIt could get a bit tricky, though, as there is rain forecast this week.:The ambitious Borders residents who want to buy their local village greenSteve Davies, owner of the Caddon View guest house in Innerleithen, said: ldquoIt has been very busy so far in our cafeacute.ldquoIt has been slow and steady in terms of accommodation, but we will be very busy again by the end of the month.ldquoWe have had people come down from Edinburgh and visitors from England, but, unsurprisingly, no-one from overseas.ldquoHopefully we can make something of this summer. The last year has been appalling and I worry another lockdown could be the final nail in the coffin for many businesses.:Record-breaking Borders runner says eating stock cubes was key to successAccording to Scotlandrsquos route map out of lockdown, the next raft of changes are set to come in on May .From this date, it is hoped council areas will be able to move to Level .According to the Scottish Government website, in Level  hospitality venues can open until .pm for the sale of food and alcohol indoors.Up to eight people from eight households can meet in a beer garden, while six adults from three households can go indoors together, the governmentrsquos website says.Clarication:The print version of this article, which appeared in the Borderon May , incorrectly stated that Rob Chisholm is the owner of the Ship Inn. In fact, Mr Chisholm is the manager of the pub. We are happy to clary this fact and we apologise for our error.

title: covid-nails-lines-nails-mean-covid
story: A leading scientist has warned of a new symptom that would showyou have already had coronavirus.Professor Tim Spector has said that people may notice changes to their fingernails after a Covid infection.Professor Spector, who is the principal investigator of the Zoe Covid Symptom Study app, said that the dference can happen evenyou did not experience any other symptoms of Covid-.Herersquos what you need to know:What do lsquoCovid nailsrsquo look like Professor Spector noted that people who have a "clear line", which creates a prominent ridge, growing out of the nail may have had Covid before.People may also notice discoloration under their nailsthey have previously had the virus.The professor said it is recognised as the nails recover after an infection. However, he adds that these are usually harmless and can be caused by any illness - meaning it is not only linked to Covid-.Do your nails look odd  COVID nails are increasingly being recognised as the nails recover after infection and the growth recovers leaving a clear line. Can occur without skin rashes and appears harmless pic QLfdrcDcmdash Tim SpectorMay , Writing on Twitter, Prof Spector said: "Do your nails look odd  COVID nails are increasingly being recognised as the nails recover after infection and the growth recovers leaving a clear line. Can occur without skin rashes and appears harmless."Several Twitter users responded to the post stating they had experienced this symptom after being unwell.Julie McGlue replied: "Myself  my husband had covid last September  we noticed we had grooves in our nails too"User pippabrunton said: "I noticed this and also hair loss  months after covid"Drizzydre wrote: "Ok but I % had nails that looked like this in March  and thatrsquos cause everyone in the show I was in in February  probably had Covid but it was before testing was a common thing but this is more proof that we actually did have it!!!!!!!!!!!"Why do the ridges appear These horizontal grooves appear on the nail after an infection and are known as Beaursquos lines.The lines are commonly found in patients who have had a viral illness. This is due to the stress that their body was under battling the virus.These have been reported among people who have experienced Covid toes or fingers when the skin has become discoloured.The lines will eventually grow out over time.Dr Tanya Bleiker, president of the British Association of Dermatologists, explained: "Dermatologists are seeing Covid Nails in some patients who have had an infection with SARS-CoV-, the virus responsible for Covid .These changes have long been recognised as Beaus lines and are transverse indents in the nail of many, or all, fingernails and sometimes toenails."They are caused by a temporary interruption of the growth of the nail due to a number of causes including febrile illnesses such as Covid- infection."These indents tend to appear two to three weeks after the illness - longer in toenails."They are harmless and grow out with time - often surprisingly a few months."

title: scottish-election-declaration-times-results---what-expect-today
story: Counts in more than half of Scotlandrsquos parliamentary constituencies are to begin today,as the country awaits the outcome of its strangest election since devolution.Votes in some  of the  constituency seats will be counted from about am on Friday, with the first results expected from noon.It is anticipated all  should be declared by Friday evening.Then, from about am on Saturday, the remaining  constituency seats will be counted, after which the regional seats will be allocated.Due to the Covid- pandemic, there is a staggered tallying up of ballots for the  Holyrood election, with all results expected to be declared by Saturday evening.Normally, counting begins immediately after the polls close at pm and continues overnight, with results confirmed in the early hours.But the need for social distancing among count staff has meant votes will be tallied from Friday.This yearrsquos election, while conducted under the constraints of coronavirus rules, is also considered to be one of the most important since the Scottish Parliament opened in .With the SNP set for another five years in government, First Minister Nicola Sturgeon will no doubt ramp up the pressure on Westminster to grant the powers for another vote on Scottish independence.Her opponents in the Tory, Labour and Liberal Democrat parties have stressed the importance of focusing on Scotlandrsquos recovery from coronavirus insteadBut the SNP leader and her party have said no referendum will be held until after the immediate health crisis is over, and they insist powers gained through independence would actually improve the recovery in Scotland.Ms Sturgeon has said another pro-independence majority in the Scottish Parliament, including the Greens and Alba Party seats, should be enough to let Scots vote again on whether they want to leave the UK.Take a look at the potential declaration times here:

title: borders-perfect-pet-competition-winner-2021-revealed
story: VELVET is the winner of our Perfect Pet competition .For nearly two months, readers of the Peeblesshire Newsand the Border sent in their votes.And now we can declare that four-year-old Velvet received the most.The Nebelung-Russian Blue cross lives in Walkerburn with her owner Roseann McGee.:How Borders pubs and hotels have been getting on since they reopened last weekWhen we spoke with Roseann about Velvet winning the pound prize, the proud owner said: ldquoI was so pleased."When I got the phone call I was so excited, I told my family and everyonersquos so excited. Shersquos a wee star.Velvet joined -year-old Roseann in January , not long before the first coronavirus lockdown.Roseann said: ldquoI got her just at the right time.ldquoI feel like we found each other ndash it was meant to be.Four-year-old Velvet from Walkerburn received the most votes. Photo: Helen BarringtonRoseann said Velvet has been "the best company, adding: ldquoI just love her so much. She gets spoiled rotten.And it seems Velvet will be getting a few more treats through her winnings.ldquoNot that I can get many more toys in this house, joked Roseann.She acquired Velvet through a rehoming charity and, although there were some hurdles to overcome, Roseann says it was all worth it.:Football: Borders teams could face Rangers and Celtic sidesplans are backedldquoShe was worth all the waiting and all the expense, Roseann said. ldquoThey [the charity] called me up out of the blue and askedI could go and pick her up in Perth. Literally within a couple of days she was settled in.Roseann, who works for Holland and Sherry in Peebles as part of the interior design department, has now ed to work after being furloughed for seven months last year.ldquoIt was just me and her [Velvet], said Roseann. ldquo[Now] shersquos waiting behind the door for me when she hears me walking up the stairs.The pet who came second is Totoro, a Pomeranian from Peebles. Owner Victoria Anderson will take home the pound prize.Harry the hamster ndash and owner Connor Finnigan ndash came third. They win pound.

title: covid-scotland-places-coronavirus-cases-week
story: The latest weeklycoronavirusfigures have been released, highlighting hotspots of Covid- per, of the population and the risk in each neighbourhood.Scotlandhad , positive cases between April  and May , which was  cases per , population and a test positivity rate of %.This is lower than last week when Scotlandhad , positive cases, which was . cases per , population and a test positivity rate of .%.: Last weeks figuresMuirhouse in Edinburgh Cityhad the most Covid cases inScotland, with  people testing positive from a population of ,.The council area with the most cases of Covid- is Glasgow City with  positive cases, which works out at . per , people.However, the area with the most Covid cases per , population was Moray with  - almost double last week.The neighbourhood with the most cases per , wasKessington East in East Dunbartonshire  cases with a population of ,.Only theShetland Islands, the Orkney Islands, and the Western Islesin Scotlandhad zero cases of Covid- over this seven-day period.

title: british-irish-lions-borders-rugby-stars-2021-squad
story: TWO Borders rugby stars have been included in Warren Gatlandrsquos -man British and Irish Lions squad to face South Africa.Scotland captain Stuart Hogg made the cut, while there was also a first call-up for Rory Sutherland at loosehead prop.Sutherland spoke of his delight at being included, after he dislocated his shoulder against France during the Six Nations.He told The Times: "I was asked to watch it [the announcement] with the team but didnt want to, I wanted to watch it on my own. I watched it on my phone in the car."A groin muscle injury in  left the -year-old bedridden and wonderinghe would be able to continue playing the sport.He added: "Going through that time I wonderedId ever play rugby again."To be in this position now, Im just over the moon. I cant wait to get stuck in."Sutherland will be the th player from Hawick to join a tour.And he is looking forward to representing his town alongside Stuart Hogg.He told The Times: "Hoggy has been on tours already and Im really looking forward to sharing that experience with him."Its a huge jersey to fill and theres a massive history behind it in Hawick."To be able to be part of that is special."Hogg was in contention to captain the squad but that responsibility has been placed on the experienced shoulders of Wales skipper Alun Wyn Jones.The Scots included in the squad are Hogg, Sutherland, Zander Ferguson, Hamish Watson, Ali Price, Finn Russell, Chris Harris and Duhan van der Merwe.Gatland announced the full squad to play in the series against South Africa this summer at .pm on Thursday . Players can join the squad later in the event of injuries or suspensions.THE LIONS  SQUAD: Mako Vunipola, Wyn Jones, Rory Sutherland, Ken Owens, Jamie George, Luke Cowan-Dickie, Tadhg Furlong, Andrew Porter, Zander Fagerson, Alun Wyn Jones, Maro Itoje, Iain Henderson, Tadhg Beirne, Jonny Hill, Courtney Lawes, Tom Curry, Justin Tipuric, Hamish Watson, Taulupe Faletau, Sam Simmonds, Jack Conan, Conor Murray, Ali Price, Gareth Davies, Dan Biggar, Owen Farrell, Finn Russell, Robbie Henshaw, Chris Harris, Bundee Aki, Stuart Hogg, Liam Williams, Anthony Watson, Louis Rees-Zammit, Duhan van der Merwe, Elliot Daly, Josh Adams

title: coronavirus-borders-sees-one-new-case-last-24-hours
story: THE Borders has recorded one new coronavirus case in the last  hours.According to Scottish Government data released at pm today , there have now been , cases of the virusin the region since the pandemic began.In the first seven days of May there have been four cases reported in the Borders.And there still remains fewer than five patients in hospital with COVID- in the region.Across Scotland there are now , coronavirus cases, and  people in hospital.

title: scottish-parliament-election-rachael-hamilton-wins-vote
story: RACHAEL Hamilton from the Scottish Conservatives has been elected as the MSP for Ettrick, Roxburgh and Berwickshire following the  Scottish Parliament election contest.Voters went to the polls yesterday , with the count held in Kelsorsquos Borders Event Centre today.Mrs Hamilton, who won the by-election in , willto Holyrood for another term after securinga majority of , votes.The total number of votes cast was , . There were  rejected ballot papers.In a speech following the declaration, Mrs Hamilton said the Conservatives in the Borders have been "going from strength to strength"."I think that speaks volumes to what the electorate want," she said."The constituents Ive been speaking to over the past few days have been absolutely resolute in the fact that they want people to be rebuilding from the pandemic - not about ision and breaking up our United Kingdom."The results in fullIan Davidson, Scottish Labour Party and Scottish Co-operative Party ndash ,Rachael Hamilton, Scottish Conservative and Unionist Party ndash ,Barbra Harvie, Scottish Green Party ndash ,Jenny Claire Marr, Scottish Liberal Democrats ndash ,Jesse Rae, Independent - Paul Wheelhouse, Scottish National Partyndash ,

title: rachael-hamilton-paul-wheelhouse-election-result-2021
story: RACHAEL Hamilton says she is ldquoabsolutely ecstatic after being re-elected as the MSP for Ettrick, Roxburgh and Berwickshire.Mrs Hamilton, of the Scottish Conservatives, received , votes in the Scottish Parliament contest, while runner-up Paul Wheelhouse from the SNP recorded ,.Mrs Hamilton, who won the by-election, will nowto Holyrood as theconstituency representative.Important to protect jobsAfter the result was declared, Mrs Hamilton told the Border : ldquoI think this is fantastic."It speaks volumes of the work my team have done and the support for the Scottish Conservatives in the Borders.ldquoI think the voters in the Borders have rejected what could have been Nicola Sturgeon calling for a hard border at Berwick. Itrsquos really important that we focus now on rebuilding the economy and looking after peoplersquos livelihoods and their incomes.ldquoItrsquos important that we protect jobs and we ensure that the NHS can get back on its feet after all this time that it has had to focus on the pandemic. There are people out there who have had cancelled operations and theyrsquore waiting for them.ldquoItrsquoll be my focus that we ensure that we just get back to normal and we concentrate on that and not a border or independence."I want to end the isionAsked what her priority for the region is, Mrs Hamilton said: ldquoMy main focus is to end the ision and work towards rebuilding the Borders. Itrsquos very dficult to do anything  other than to rebuild an economy and protect jobs.ldquoI think itrsquos important to look after young people and their education because obviously therersquos a massive catch-up exercise that needs to be done because kids havenrsquot had face-to-face learning, theyrsquove been learning from home. Theyrsquore only just back at school.ldquoThere are young people who are going to have suffered from the fact that they havenrsquot had that face-to-face learning and I think itrsquos important that we resource our schools to ensure that those kids can catch up.Wheelhouse disappointedMr Wheelhouse also spoke to the Border after the declaration.He said:ldquoIrsquom obviously disappointed because I dearly wanted to represent this constituency, but I congratulate Rachael for her win.ldquoI take comfort from the fact that our vote has increased. Itrsquos the largest number of votes wersquove had in this seat and the largest share of the votes wersquove had in this seat so thatrsquos encouraging, but clearly I wanted to win so Irsquom disappointed in that.ldquoIrsquom pleased for the activists that we got an increase in the votes for all their efforts.ldquoItrsquos a small swing but itrsquos signicant that wersquore still on the up. Irsquove yet to see what the pattern is across the country, we know that wersquove got a tough task here in terms of the constitutional question causes a polarisation in the electorate.ldquoMaybe people are voting on constitutional grounds rather than necessarily who they think could be the best representative for the area.Wersquore not going awayReflecting on the campaign, Mr Wheelhouse said: ldquoWersquoll keep plugging away, being positive. We put across a really positive campaign which Irsquom very proud of.ldquoWe didnrsquot focus on attacking the opposition, we focused on showing what we could do for the area and I hope that might inspire some ideas for others to pick up.ldquoI just hope that Ettrick, Roxburgh and Berwickshire gets good representation for the next five years, it does deserve it.ldquoI hope for this constituencyrsquos sake that Rachael can step up to the plate and can do that but wersquoll certainly still be around.ldquoWersquore not going away. If she fails wersquoll be looking to take the seat next time.

title: galashiels-dalgettys-bakery-helps-flower-projects-town
story: CUSTOMERS at a Galashiels bakery have raised almost pound to help add colour to the town.For many years, volunteers have tasked themselves with maintaining local gardens.But the coronavirus pandemic meant they have recently been prevented from getting their hands dirty.Now, the townrsquos community council is launching its Floral Gala project, which aims to raise money to brighten up the area.And customers at Alex Dalgetty and Sons in Bank Street have already given pound to help the efforts of Floral Gala and Gala in Bloom.:Dog broke its leg during walk on popular route in the Borders, meeting hearsA spokesperson for the community council said: ldquoThe community council successfully applied for and received funding from Build a Better Gala to further support the Floral Gala Project.ldquoThis funding will enable the community council to purchase a number of barrier and three-tier fountain planters which will be situated in the Douglas Bridge and Channel Street areas of the town centre.ldquoThese planters will be deployed in June and will provide much needed colour in and around the town.ldquoGalashiels Community Council would like to thank Energise Galashiels Trust for their assistance with this project.:Football: Borders teams could face Rangers and Celtic sidesplans are backedThe new Floral Gala initiative, led by chairwoman Judith Cleghorn, is aiming to bring the flora back to the town but on a much grander scale.A lot of hard work has gone into securing funding from Energise Gala, Haywardrsquos Trust and Focus Centre, among others.And a crowdfunding page has been set up and is ready to be launched in the hope that residents will dig deep to help keep the town looking its best.John Gray, from Gala in Bloom, said: ldquoNow that the floral displays in Bank Street gardens, Old Gala House, War Memorial and Gala Aisle are the responsibility of the community council , the greatest challenge will be to raise the funds required annually to retain those floral displays.:Galashiels: What you will see the next time you walk along Channel StreetldquoPrior to COVID, the Galashiels councillors had agreed to re-establish some assistance from the parking money, but because of the very limited use of the car parks, this assistance is not expected to be available for this summerrsquos planting.ldquoThe community council is grateful for monies already offered from the Hayward Sanderson Trust, Galashiels British Legion, Galashiels Rotary Club, from the customers of Alex Dalgetty Sons Bakers and theGray Sanderson Trust and, together with monies from the CC funds, this year is affordable.ldquoHowever, to prepare for future years we will be launching an appeal to lsquoSave the Public Gardens Fundrsquo and we are also looking for volunteers to join the Gala in Bloom group, who have already been offered assistance from a Girl Guide group and the ex-Braw Lads and Lasses.

title: election-snp-candidate-christine-grahame-wins-seat
story: CHRISTINE Grahame from the Scottish National Partyhas been elected as the MSP for Midlothian South, Tweeddale and Lauderdale following the  Scottish Parliament election.Voters in Scotland went to the polls on Thursday , with counts held across the country yesterday and today .After ballot papers were totted up in Kelso today, Ms Grahame was declared the victor in her constituency. She won the previous Holyrood contest in .This time round, Ms Grahame received a total of , votes - up from , in .Second place has gone toScottish Conservative candidate Shona Haslam .In Ms Grahames victory speech, she sent a message to Prime Minister Boris Johnson.She said: ldquoI would like to say this to the electoratehellip Isnrsquot it wonderful to have such a turnout across Scotland for a Scottish Parliament election ldquoWhether you have voted for me or not, as I have done for the last times I have been elected, I will work for you no matter how you voted.ldquoAnd I know that is true of all the MSPs in the Scottish Parliament. Wersquore not partisan, any of us, when wersquore working for our constituents.ldquoAcross Scotland, I want to say thishellip First of all, this is the best constituency in Scotland,not the entire world.ldquoAnd the second thing I want to say about the vote is thishellip We will have, for the fourth term, an SNP government. And that is extraordinary.ldquoSecondly, there will be a majority in that parliament who have voted for people to have a choice that is to have a referendum, at an appropriate time, on whether or not Scotland becomes an independent country.ldquoAnd I want to say this to Boris Johnsonhellip What is the democratic way for the Scottish people to voice their will, other thanto go to the ballot box and, with proportional representation,a majority of MSPs who want a referendum ldquoIf that is not the way to do it, Boris, you tell us the way to do it.RESULTS:Christine Grahameshyndash ,.Shona Haslamndash ,.Katherine Sangsterndash ,AC Mayndash ,Dominic Ashmolendash ,Michael James Banksndash

title: election-result-christine-grahame-shona-haslam-react
story: CHRISTINE Grahame says she is ldquoabsolutely thrilled about increasing hermajority in Midlothian South, Tweeddale and Lauderdale.Voters went to the polls on Thursdayfor the Scottish Parliament election contest.And todaySNP candidate Ms Grahame was declared the winner at the count in Kelso.The re-elected Ms Grahame received a total of , votes - up from , in .Her majority has risen from , to ,.Great that people turned outFollowing thedeclaration, Ms Grahame said: ldquoI am absolutely thrilled to have increased my majority, even with a Green candidate standing.ldquoThey took , votes and I actually thought my vote would go down, but Irsquove managed to increase it.ldquoThat, I hope, is vindication of the years I have represented this area, of the local campaign, of my campaign team and the national campaign team.ldquoIt was a strange campaign. I had never met any of the candidates personally, except for Shona Haslam, until today.ldquoI wasnrsquot able to go door-knocking and kept very low key. There were no hustings, no atmosphere but the great thing is, is that people turned out.ldquoMaybe we should do it this way every time, without the COVID.ldquoMy priority now is getting back to my desk to deal with cases - cases that have to be continued and cases that I had to park, as I wasnrsquot allowed to do them during this period.ldquoCases will be my priority. I am already activated. My parliamentary pass is live, so I can go back.ldquoObviously, not this weekend. I might go and see my grandchildren as they have not seen me for ages.ldquoBut on Monday, Irsquoll be back at my desk.Haslam enjoyed campaignSecond place went to Scottish Conservative candidate Shona Haslam .Mrs Haslam, the leader of Scottish Borders Council leader, told this newspaper:ldquoI am really pleased with the increase in the vote share.ldquoI think with the turnout being so high, it was always going to be dficult to call, so I am really pleased we have managed to increase our vote share here.ldquoI love campaigning, getting out and about to meet people and talking about the issues that are really important to people.ldquoI have really enjoyed this campaign.Askedshe had a message to her voters, she said: ldquoI wonrsquot let you down. I will be back.The turnout for the Midlothian South, Tweeddale and Lauderdale constituency was  per cent .That is an increase on , when it was at . per cent .RESULTS:Christine Grahamendash ,Shona Haslamndash ,Katherine Sangsterndash ,AC Mayndash ,Dominic Ashmolendash ,Michael James Banksndash

title: selkirk-seven-new-shops-open-amid-business-boom-town
story: A BORDERS townis said to be experiencing a ldquorenaissance, with seven new shops having thrown open their doors recently.A iety of stores have joined the high street in Selkirk, some of them offering products and services previously not found in the town.A spokesperson for Explore Selkirk said: ldquoSelkirk is going through a renaissance, and the town has a real feeling of optimism.ldquoWhilst other high streets have struggled to keep shops open during the pandemic, Selkirk has seen seven new shops open in the town centre.The Border toured the town with Explore Selkirk, meeting the business owners.Many were upbeat about launching during the pandemic.Number One deli. Photo: Phil WilkinsonldquoTo be honest, it probably couldnrsquot have happened at a better time, said Tracey Ward, who runs Number One delicatessen with her husband Trevor.She added: ldquoSome folk thought we were mad opening up in the middle of a pandemic but itrsquos been really good ndash in fact wersquove been able to concentrate on it as well.The couple also own The Fleece Bar and Kitchen in the town.Trevor added: ldquoWersquove been open eight weeks now. We were well supported by the local community when the first lockdown came.ldquoTherersquos a lot of good will out there and wersquore thankful for that.The Peony Rose Coffee House. Photo: Phil WilkinsonCatherine Inglis took over the Selkirk Deli and renamed it the Peony Rose Coffee House.She offered on-the-door takeaways before being allowed to welcome guests indoors last week.Catherine said: ldquoItrsquos been a challenge.ldquoBut Irsquove been very lucky as Irsquove had the opportunity to get it how I want.ldquoEvery cloud has a silver lining.For some local residents, searching for tools and DIY items use to mean having to travel to shops in other Borders towns now, however, shoppers looking for lightbulbs, tools and even pet supplies can find them closer to home at Ideal Hardware  Home Essentials.Lorna Han is the owner of the store, which opened in October.She told this newspaper: ldquoBusiness has been steady, wersquove been well supported.Meanwhile, on Market Place, The General Storerepairs broken items and sells upcycled goods.The General Store. Photo: Phil WilkinsonFounded by Sue Briggs and Dot Torrance, the repair shop has been operating since before Christmas - but the retail side of The General Store has only just opened.The teamrsquos ethos is that damage doesnrsquot make something useless.ldquoSomething can be beautul evenitrsquos damaged, Sue said.They hope that by offering repair services, as well as selling beautul upcycled items made by local creators, they can start a conversation about eco-friendly living and making the most of what we have now.Basanti India. Photo: Phil WilkinsonBasanti India ndash which sells ethically sourced gts and accessories and did have a temporary presence in the town ndash has now moved to permanent premises.Owner Imogen Kennedy told us: ldquoI lived in India for  years I know all my providers.ldquoI started in the pop-up on Tower Street ndash itrsquos a great launch pad.ldquoItrsquos really nice to have a permanent place on the high street.Skinnys. Photo: Phil WilkinsonAnd for anyone with a sweet tooth, Skinnyrsquos on Market Place serves waffles, ice-cream and a range of lunchtime snacks.Co-owner Shirley Singhtoor said: ldquoWersquove had lots of interest.ldquoWe just want to spread the word and see how things go.Burnside Gallery. Photo: Phil WilkinsonAlso newly opened is the Burnside Gallery and Frames, run by Javier Ternero and Charly Murray.They said: ldquoSelkirk has been wonderful, very welcoming. Therersquos a ersity of businesses here.For more information on the range of businesses in Selkirk, you can visit: exploreselkirk

title: asda-announce-major-changes-coming-every-uk-store
story: Asda has published its first environmental, social and governancereport and with it promised changes affecting every store in the UK.The supermarket giant has set out its commitments to a sustainable business strategy in the future.The report interviewed , customers and found that shoppers had three priorities.According to the report, customers want more affordable greener choices, commitments to reduce single-use plastic and cutting food waste.The supermarket said it is now committed to becoming a net zero carbon business by .Asda ndash one of the UKrsquos big six UK supermarket retailers ndash will join rivals such as Sainsburyrsquos and Aldi in becoming more environmentally friendly.Asda bosses plan to remove three billion pieces of plastic from products within the next four years.They also want to ensure its top  commodities, including cotton and cocoa, are sustainably sourced by .The chain has also pledged to increase the proportion of own-brand products that are low in fat, sugar and salt to % by .Roger Burnley, Asda CEO and President, said:ldquoAsda has always been a retailer that sits at the heart of the communities it serves and the events of the last  months have highlighted the important role we play in helping to tackle societal challenges.ldquoDespite the challenges of the pandemic, we have not lost sight of our wider ESG responsibilities and this report provides an update of where Asda is now on the issues that matter most to our colleagues, customers and communities and importantly where we want to be in the future."It builds upon our existing create change for better commitments and the resilience we have shown during the last  months means we are well positioned to help customers make greener, healthier and responsible choices when they shop with us.

title: 20mph-limits-scottish-borders-council-starts-consultation
story: BORDERS residents can now have their say on the mph speed trial which began last year.As part of the Spaces for People programme, the reduced limit was introduced in more than  towns and villages in the region.And todayan online consultation has been launched, so people can share their views on the trial ndash for example, whether they think any roads should change back to mph.Gordon Edgar, Scottish Borders Councilrsquos executive member for infrastructure, transport and travel, said: ldquoThe mph trial, which has been in place for the last seven months, was introduced to make it easier and safer for people to walk, cycle and wheel for everyday journeys.ldquoWith it having been in place for a signicant amount of time during the coronavirus pandemic, we now want to get feedback from Borderers as to how effective it has been."As part of the consultation, which will run until June , contributors will be asked how the scheme impacted travel and whether they chose to walk or cycle more as a result.During the trial, data was collected to show how the new limits affected average speeds. The results can be accessed at scottishborders.tracsis-tads conduit bordersOne example is the .mph reduction in average speed at Hillside Terrace, Selkirk .Mr Edgar said: "Whether you are a keen walker or cyclist, have a business which operates in the Borders, live in this part of the country or drive on the roads across the region, I would urge you to feedback your specic experiences with the trial and how it has impacted your travel.ldquoItrsquos important that we get as many responses to this consultation as possible, to help inform any permanent changes the council makes following the trial.ldquoThese will be made purely on an inidual basis, based on the specic needs of each community, the feedback we receive through the consultation and the impartial data collected across theof the trial.The consultations findings will be reported later this year, detailing which parts of the scheme will be kept ndashany.Cyclists, pedestrians, residents, business owners and drivers are all asked to contribute to the consultation.To share your views, visit: www.scotborders.gov.uk mphThe speed limits were introduced by Scottish Borders Council, working with the Scottish Government, Transport Scotland and Sustrans.

title: covid-scotland-rules-meeting-inside-home
story: From next Monday you will be allowed to meet another household inside your own home for the first time this year.All council areas in Scotlandare expected to move from level three to at leastlevel two from Monday, May .The change in restrictions coincides with the news that theCovid- alert level in the UK has been downgraded after a "consistent" fall in cases, hospital admissions and deaths.These changes will mean that you will be allowed to meet indoors, including homes, as long as you stick to the restrictions.Heres what you need to know:Meeting in homesThe maximum number of people who can meet indoors socially in a home is fourwhich can be from twohouseholds, including for overnight stays.Children under the age of  do not count towards the total number of people or households meeting outside but do count towards household numbers indoorsChildren under  do not need to maintain physical distance from others.When you meet people from another household indoors you should:Minimise the number of meetings you have with people from other households each day.Stay at least twometres apart from anyone who is not part of your household.Maintain hand and cough hygiene.Avoid touching hard surfaces with your hands.Wash your hands when you arrive, when you leave, when you get home and especially before eating or after touching surfaces.Not sharing food or utensils.Keep rooms well ventilated,possible ndash consider opening windows or a door.

title: coronavirus-borders-weekend-cases-shown-latest-data
story: THE Borders has recorded three new cases of coronavirus over the weekend, figures show.The Scottish Government publishes an update every day at pm.Today , the figures show the Borders has recorded , cases since the pandemicbegan - meaning the tally has risen by three since Friday .The Borders data shows there are still fewer than five people in hospital with the virus, which has been the case since February .

title: michael-gove-makes-scottish-borders-council-comment-bbc
story: THE leader of Scottish Borders Councilsays she was ldquodelighted to hear Michael Goversquos comments on the BBCrsquos Andrew Marr Show.When Mr Marr interviewed the Minister for the Cabinet Office on Sunday , Mr Gove suggested the UK Government is keen to work closely with local authorities in Scotland ndash including SBC.SBC leader Shona Haslam, also of the Conservatives, said: "I am absolutely delighted that the UK Government will be supporting councils in this way."When Mr Gove was interviewed, he said that as part of the UK Governmentrsquos lsquoLevelling Uprsquo project, Whitehall could work directly with Scottish councils to provide funding.When asked by Mr Marrthese plans were aiming to bypass the Scottish Government and put the Scottish Parliament "back in its box", Mr Gove said: "Certainly not."We want to work with both."I think its critically important we work with the Scottish Government and with local government as well."We have already seen opportunities to do just that."When we announced that we were going to work with both Holyrood, but also local authorities, I think it was the leader of Glasgow council ndash an SNP politician ndash who welcomed that, along with the leaders of Aberdeen council, Borders council and so on."To my mind, its an example of Team UK working together in everyones interests."lsquoLevelling Uprsquo is a Westminster White Paper, to be published later this year, which "will focus on challenges including improving living standards, growing the private sector and increasing and spreading opportunity".Mrs Haslam told the Border : "I am very excited about the opportunity to work with the UK Government on funding proposals and have already had several useful meetings with our MPs for this area and the Scotland Office.ldquoI would encourage anyone with ideas for local projects to contact their local councillor to discuss options.

title: covid-scotland-can-level-2-lockdown
story: All council areas in Scotland, with the possible exception of Moray,are expected to move from Level to at least Level from Monday, May .The change in restrictions coincides with the news that theCovid- alert level in the UK has been downgraded after a "consistent" fall in cases, hospital admissions and deaths.The four chief medical officers of the UK have said the threat level should be lowered from "Level "to "Level ", thanks to the success of the vaccination programme and social distancing restrictions.These changes will include, but are not limited to, being able to meet inside a home, drinking alcohol inside a pub or restaurant, the reintroduction of adult contact sports and meeting eight peoplefrom eight households outdoors.Here is what you can and cannot do in Level  lockdown:Can I meet peopleinside my home Yes but the maximum number of people who can meet indoors socially ina homeis fourwhich can be from twohouseholds, including for overnight stays.Can I get a pint or a meal indoors Yes. Indoors it will be sixadults from threehouseholds in an indoor public place like a cafeacute, pub or restaurant.Outdoors eight peoplefrom eight households will be allowed.Under s do not count towards the total number of people or households meeting outside but do count towards household numbers indoors.AmI allowed to goto the shops Yes, all non-essential shops will be open for business so you will be able to head to your favourite retailers.Can I travel around Scotland Yes, you will be able to travel anywhere across Scotland and the UK.However, as lockdown levels change, people in Level must not enter Levels - or Level  area unless for a permitted reason.Can I go on holiday Staycations will be permitted with travel restrictions lted and tourist accommodation will reopen.However, socialising rules must still apply.It is expected that the Scottish Government will today announce that people in Scotland will be able to travel to some foreign destinations without the need to quarantine on their .It will be part of a traffic lights system, similar to that in England, and will come into effect on May .Countries are to be classied as green, amber and red and a review will take place every four weeks.Will bars, restaurants andcafes be open Yes, restaurants, cafeacutes, pubs and bars can open indoors until .pm with two-hour pre-booked slots.They can open outdoors within local licensing conditions for the consumption of food and alcoholic drinks.The maximum number of people you can meet indoors in a restaurant, cafeacute, pub or bar is sixwhich can be from up to threeseparate households.The maximum number of people you can meet outdoors in a restaurant, cafeacute, pub or bar is eightwhich can be from up to eight separate households.Takeaway service will also continue to be open.Am I able to go to the gym Yes, gyms and indoor sports facilities including swimming pools and leisure centres will be open for inidual exercise.Personal training and coaching are also permitted.Group activity will be permitted for under s.Can I play contact sports Yes, all organised outdoor sports are allowed provided appropriate safety measures are followed.Indoor contact sports are not permitted, except for professional sport.Will cinemas be open Yes, small seated indoor events are permitted with a maximum of  people. This includes theatres, bingo halls,music venues, comedy clubs,amusement arcades and casinos.Guidance is being produced which may allow higher capacities to be agreed with the local authority Scottish Government depending on the event.Can Isee my friends and family Yes, groups ofeight peoplefrom eight households will be allowed.It is worth noting that under s do not count towards restricted numbers or households outdoors.Can I go into stadiums and attend events Yes.Outdoor seated and open space events are advised to operate with a maximum capacity of  people.Outdoor grouped standing events are advised to operate with a maximum capacity of  people.Small seated indoor events are advised to operate with a maximum of  people.Can I take public transport You should continue to active travelwhere possible and avoid car sharing with people outside of your extended household.Face coverings compulsory on public transport and, due to limited capacity,you are using public transport then plan ahead.What about childcare Nurseries, childminders and regulated school-age childcare providers are open with standard protective measures are in place.Informal childcare such as family and friendsare permitted.Can my child take part in after school activities Yes, but it will be subject to guidance.Can zoos and tourist attractions reopen Yes, all visitors centres can reopen for business.Should I still work from home You are encouraged to work from home where possible.Can I visit people in the hospital Yes, but the recommended family support from at least onevisitor per patient.Am I able to visit my loved ones in care homes Yes, however, the recommended minimum of twovisits per week, one person at a time.Will college and universities be open Yes, but it willbeblended learning.Can I get married Yes, and  people are allowed to attend the ceremony and thewedding reception.Alcohol is also permitted.Am I allowed to attend a funeral A maximum of  people are allowed to attend a funeral service and alcohol is permitted.Can I visit my place of worship Yes, places of worship will be open.Will libraries be open Yes, public buildings such as libraries or community centres will be open.Some public buildings will operate an online booking system and some may have dedicated opening times for high-risk groupsAre driving lessons allowed Yes, driving lessons are allowed.Can I get work done indoors Work, such as home decorating, repairs etc areallowed indoors.Am I allowed to move home Yes, you are allowed to move home.Will hairdressers and beauty services stay open Yes, all close contact services, including mobile, may operate providing they follow Scottish Government guidance to ensure the safety of customers and staff.

title: nine-year-old-dubai-dj-scratches-way-fame-world-contest
story: A nine-year-old girl who lives in Dubai is scratching her way to the top as a DJ in world competitions.Michelle Rasul was already spinning turntables, scratching hip-hop records and making the beats drop four years ago, when she was just learning how to read and write.Four years later, she is one of the worldrsquos top DJs and competed in this yearrsquos global championship.At her home in the skyscraper-studded city of Dubai, the turntable whiz from Azerbaijan nodded her baseball cap-adorned head to the beat and showed off her skills scratching, cutting and fading.vw,vw,px, px"Michelle Rasul enjoys scratching her turntable in the lobby of her apartment building in Dubai Her tiny fingers flew across the turntable as she created a sizzling landscape of electric audio effects and recalled how she got her start as a child turntable celebrity ndash which, in fact, was not all that long ago.ldquoI looked at my dad while he was practising DJ-ing and I saw him and was like, lsquoWow, is he doing magic or something  Hersquos a real magician, bro!rsquo Michelle told the Associated Press, bubbling with enthusiasm.ldquoWhen I turned five, on my birthday, I told him, lsquoDad, I want to be a world famous DJ. Irsquom going to start practisingrsquo.As though recounting a decades-long career, she grinned and added: ldquoAnd the rest is history.vw,vw,px, px"Michelle Rasul chases a friendrsquos dog at a park near her house Michelle, the youngest-ever contestant in the DMC World DJ Championship, ranked th out of  DJ stars from around the world in the Portablist category this year, the global portable story: Hannah OHanlonUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  At the start of the pandemic in March we took the decision to make online access to our news free of charge by taking down our paywall. At a time where accurate information about Covid- was vital to our community, this was the right decision # even though it meant a drop in our income. In order to help safeguard the future of our journalism, the time has now come to reinstate our paywall.However, rest assured that access to all Covid related news will still remain free.To access all other news will require a subscription, as it did pre-pandemic.The good news is that for the whole of December we will be running a special discounted offer to get  months access for the price of one month. Thank you for supporting us during this incredibly challenging time.Campbeltown mother-of-two Iona MacLean is inspirational for leading the campaign to raise funds for a swingset for people of all abilities at Jock#s Adventure Playground.This inclusive equipment, which is designed to be suitable for those with cognitive and physical disabilities, will not only benefit Iona#s son but many, many other children.Iona said often people don#t realise the need for such equipment until it is their own child, grandchild, niece or nephew who could benefit from it.There is already a wheelchair accessible roundabout at Jock#s Adventure Playground but it is currently in need of repair, meaning children with physical disabilities cannot use any of the equipment.This is something worth bearing in mind when installing or updating playpark equipment in the future because, as Iona said, all children deserve to play.With a pledge of £, from an external funder already secured, the campaigners are seeking the additional £, required to purchase the swings.This is a substantial amount to raise but allowing children of all abilities access to play equipment is priceless.Campbeltown is renowned for its community spirit and generosity. There are lots of brilliant causes worth supporting butever there was one the whole community could get behind, it is surely this.Let#s make play inclusive in Campbeltown.

title: letters april 23 2021
story: Hannah OHanlonUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  At the start of the pandemic in March we took the decision to make online access to our news free of charge by taking down our paywall. At a time where accurate information about Covid- was vital to our community, this was the right decision # even though it meant a drop in our income. In order to help safeguard the future of our journalism, the time has now come to reinstate our paywall.However, rest assured that access to all Covid related news will still remain free.To access all other news will require a subscription, as it did pre-pandemic.The good news is that for the whole of December we will be running a special discounted offer to get  months access for the price of one month. Thank you for supporting us during this incredibly challenging time.I recently wrote to the Campbeltown Courier on behalf of Campbeltown Community Council regarding the amount of dog poo not being uplted by a minority of dog owners.It seems our appeal has been heeded as there appears to be less dog poo left lying so thank you to this minority.Remember to scoop it, bag it and bin it.This is National Pet Month and I#m urging animal lovers to take part in the Blue Cross #Rescue Run# to help the charity care for pets in need.Complete . miles between May  and  however you like – hop, skip, jump, walk or run you can even take part with your dog.Every penny raised will go towards helping the thousands of homeless, abandoned, sick and injured pets the charity takes in each year and each participant receives a special medal when they have completed their virtual marathon.To find out more and book your place, visit www.bluecross.org.uk rescuerun[Note: the following comprises an overall intro followed by two component letters as part of one item]With the Scottish Government expected at the time of writing to confirm that shops in Scotland will be able to reopen on April , the Scottish Retail Consortium and  trade union Usdaw have come together to ask Scots to play their part in creating a safe and enjoyable retail environment for other customers and shop staff.Retailers and shop workers have worked incredibly hard and responsibly to keep customers and staff safe throughout the pandemic. Retailers in Scotland have invested tens of millions of pounds on safety measures including plexiglass screens, queue management systems, social distancing signage and floor markings, better ventilation, cleaning and hygiene. Shop workers have ensured the nation was supplied and fed throughout the past thirteen dficult months.The reopening of non-essential shops and ability of food-to-go retailers to resume welcoming customers in-store will mark a crucial milestone for Scottish retail and the wider supply chain. Retail is Scotland#s largest private sector employer. So-called non-essential stores have been compelled to close in Scotland for  consecutive days.The SRC and Usdaw encourage shoppers to:Across Scotland, thousands of shops which have been shuttered for four long months are looking forward to getting back to doing what they do best — serving their customers.Reopening is good news for our economy, for jobs and for our local communities. It has never been more important to play our part in keeping our towns, cities and retail destinations vibrant.Every purchase from a shop helps support jobs in local retail and throughout the supply chain. Retailers and their colleagues continue to work around the clock to maintain a safe shopping experience, so customers can have the confidence toto their favourite stores.If we all follow the necessary physical distancing and hygiene measures and show consideration to those around us, including shop staff who are doing a dficult job, then everyone will be better off.The reopening of stores on Monday offers a leline for many retailers. That is good news in terms of helping to safeguard jobs, but the virus is still out there.We expect employers to conduct full risk assessments, follow the agreed guidance and ensure that customers are fully informed of the necessary safety measures.Shoppers need to play their part in helping to limit the spread of the virus and avoid further lockdowns by following the rules and respecting staff.Regrettably, throughout this appalling pandemic, incidents of abuse towards shop workers doubled and Covid safety measures have now become signicant flashpoints. Abuse should never be part of the job and shop workers – who played a vital role in getting food and medicine into our homes during the pandemic – deserve our thanks and respect.In January, the Scottish Parliament unanimously voted for a ground-breaking new law to protect shop workers. Usdaw campaigned for many years to secure these legal protections and we will continue to work hard to ensure that shop workers are protected and treated with the respect they deserve.The national charity for older people is encouraging people to get moving every day next month as part of a new fundraising activity challenge.Throughout May, Age Scotland is asking people across the country to Spring into Action to help support older people in Scotland.Fundraisers can take part however they choose, but the most important thing is to make sure they are active every day.All funds raised by Spring into Action participants will go towards Age Scotland#s vital services, including the national friendship line, which offers a place older people can turn tothey are in need of support, comfort and reassurance or even just missing a friendly voice.Running and walking events have always been a great way to help raise vital funds and, even with many regular events unfortunately cancelled over the past year, we#ve been overwhelmed by the kindness and generosity shown by fundraisers still going above and beyond.We hope to see as many people as possible taking up our challenge to Spring into Action this May. With nights getting lighter and better weather on the horizon, this is a great excuse to get out and about and support a worthy cause at the same time.#Whether you run one mile, walk five, or design your own challenge, your fundraising efforts will be making a real dference for older people in Scotland.#The money you raise will fund vital services like our friendship line. Every week we receive hundreds of calls from older people looking for support. Many are lonely and isolated and just want to hear a friendly voice. We listen, provide comfort and friendship and let them know someone cares.#No one should feel like they have no one to turn to. To help us be there for every older person who needs us, sign up to the challenge today. to Age Scotland#s Spring into Action challenge or find further information at www.age.scot SpringIntoAction

title: thought for the week april 23 2021
story: Hannah OHanlonUpdated:   , : amLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  At the start of the pandemic in March we took the decision to make online access to our news free of charge by taking down our paywall. At a time where accurate information about Covid- was vital to our community, this was the right decision # even though it meant a drop in our income. In order to help safeguard the future of our journalism, the time has now come to reinstate our paywall.However, rest assured that access to all Covid related news will still remain free.To access all other news will require a subscription, as it did pre-pandemic.The good news is that for the whole of December we will be running a special discounted offer to get  months access for the price of one month. Thank you for supporting us during this incredibly challenging time.We enjoy the snowdrops and daffodils coming to le in our gardens and beautul parks, the sounds of birds chirping away as they eat from bird feeders and the bleating of newborn lambs.The dark cold months of winter remind me of those tough times we endure in our Christian lives, times where it seems there is no hope, as you face your dark, cold and dficult situation.Yet we manage to survive the winter by keeping our homes warm with heaters and wood burning fireplaces and consuming countless cups of tea, coffee, soup and hot chocolate, while holding onto the truth, that spring and summer will .I am aware the ongoing lockdown has been tough and dark for many of us, causing many challenges like loneliness, depression and uncertainty about what this year has in store for us.As Christians, we get the privilege of being able to connect and press into God during these dark and cold times in our lives.It is His continuing presence, His faithfulness, His love, His care and His commitment to us that equips us to endure and persevere, bringing us into the times of new growth and le as we soak in His warmth, His love and His light.Let us look forward to the warmer months, knowing that the dark and cold times are always only but a season in our lives.

title: paying tribute to islay musician ian carmichael
story: Hannah OHanlonUpdated:   , : pmLikeGoogle +TweetEmailWant to  At the start of the pandemic in March we took the decision to make online access to our news free of charge by taking down our paywall. At a time where accurate information about Covid- was vital to our community, this was the right decision # even though it meant a drop in our income. In order to help safeguard the future of our journalism, the time has now come to reinstate our paywall.However, rest assured that access to all Covid related news will still remain free.To access all other news will require a subscription, as it did pre-pandemic.The good news is that for the whole of December we will be running a special discounted offer to get  months access for the price of one month. Thank you for supporting us during this incredibly challenging time.Ian won the Mòd Gold Medal in  in Stirling and I know he had a wonderful reputation among musicians and singers who shared a stage with him through the years.Most of the information in this piece was kindly passed to me by one such man — Willie Cameron, Acharacle, who described Ian to me as #a powerful trained voice#, #a very popular entertainer#, and, most of all, #a lovely man#.Willie played with him at ious cèilidhs round the city where Ian was always a welcomed guest. Ian also appeared regularly for a few years in the s at the Park Bar when the pub held a mid-week cèilidh at which Ian alternated weekly with Dougie Gillespie. These were the good old days of the Park Bar lock-in where the craic is stillIan#s we, Mary, would always be on hand to collect him. While those light-hearted and often impromptu cèilidhs were legendary, it should not be forgotten that Ian also had a successful television and recording career.He appeared on TV a number of timesand recorded several albums — some under his own name, others with George Smith and The Hebrideans, and one with David Silver on the Lismor Label.Like so many of his generation — including more than three quarters of his classmates in school — Ian was a native Gaelic speaker who first began learning English at five years old and only then, in his own words, #like a foreigner starting from scratch#.Perhaps not surprisingly, the language and culture remained very close to his heartIan#s own contribution to keeping his beloved culture alive is unquantiable. While the singers, musicians, and characters of that era will never be replaced, the mantle now passes to generations such as my ownto ensure his wish for Gaelic#s
