title: covid-scotland-can-level-2-lockdown
story: The change in restrictions coincides with the news that theCovid- alert level in the UK has been downgraded after a "consistent" fall in cases, hospital admissions and deaths.The four chief medical officers of the UK have said the threat level should be lowered from "level "to "level ", thanks to the success of the vaccination programme and social distancing restrictions.These changes will include, but are not limited to, being able to meet inside a home, drinking alcohol inside a pub or restaurant, the reintroduction of adult contact sports and meeting eight peoplefrom eight households outdoors.Here is what you can and cannot do in Level  lockdown:Yes but the maximum number of people who can meet indoors socially ina homeis fourwhich can be from twohouseholds, including for overnight stays.Yes. Indoors it will be sixadults from threehouseholds in an indoor public place like a cafeacute, pub or restaurant.Outdoors eight peoplefrom eight households will be allowed.Under s do not count towards the total number of people or households meeting outside but do count towards household numbers indoors.Yes, all non-essential shops will be open for business so you will be able to head to your favourite retailers.Yes, you will be able to travel anywhere across Scotland and the UK.However, as lockdown levels change, people in Level must not enter Levels - or Level  area unless for a permitted reason.Staycations will be permitted with travel restrictions lted and tourist accommodation will reopen.However, socialising rules must still apply.It is expected that the Scottish Government will today announce that people in Scotland will be able to travel to some foreign destinations without the need to quarantine on their .It will be part of a traffic lights system, similar to that in England, and will come into effect on  May.Countries are to be classied as green, amber and red and a review will take place every four weeks.Yes, restaurants, cafeacutes, pubs and bars can open indoors until : with two-hour pre-booked slots.They can open outdoors within local licensing conditions for the consumption of food and alcoholic drinks.The maximum number of people you can meet indoors in a restaurant, cafeacute, pub or bar is sixwhich can be from up to threeseparate households.The maximum number of people you can meet outdoors in a restaurant, cafeacute, pub or bar is eightwhich can be from up to eight separate households.Takeaway service will also continue to be open.Yes, gyms and indoor sports facilities including swimming pools and leisure centres will be open for inidual exercise.Personal training and coaching are also permitted,Group activity will be permitted for under s.Yes, all organised outdoor sports are allowed provided appropriate safety measures are followed.Indoor contact sports are not permitted, except for professional sport.Yes, small seated indoor events are permitted with a maximum of  people. This includes theatres, bingo halls,music venues, comedy clubs,amusement arcades and casinos.Guidance is being produced which may allow higher capacities to be agreed with the local authority Scottish Government depending on the event.Yes, groups ofeight peoplefrom eight households will be allowed.It is worth noting that under s do not count towards restricted numbers or households outdoors.Yes.Outdoor seated and open space events are advised to operate with a maximum capacity of  people.Outdoor grouped standing events are advised to operate with a maximum capacity of  people.Small seated indoor events are advised to operate with a maximum of  people.You should continue to active travelwhere possible and avoid car sharing with people outside of your extended household.Face coverings compulsory on public transport and, due to limited capacity,you are using public transport then plan ahead.Nurseries, childminders and regulated school-age childcare providers are open with standard protective measures are in place.Informal childcare such as family and friendsare permitted.Yes, but it will be subject to guidance.Yes, all visitors centres can reopen for business.You are encouraged to work from home where possible.Yes, but the recommended family support from at least onevisitor per patient.Yes, but it willbeblended learning.Yes, and  people are allowed to attend the ceremony and thewedding reception.Alcohol is also permitted.A maximum of  people are allowed to attend a funeral service and alcohol is permitted.Yes, places of worship will be open.Yes, public buildings such as libraries or community centres will be open.Some public buildings will operate an online booking system and some may have dedicated opening times for high-risk groupsYes, driving lessons are allowed.Work, such as home decorating, repairs etc areallowed indoors.Yes, you are allowed to move home.Yes, all close contact services, including mobile, may operate providing they follow Scottish Government guidance to ensure the safety of customers and staff.

title: covid-scotland-nicola-sturgeon-lockdown-update----watch-expect
story: The First Minister, whois to address the nation on Tuesday, is expected to confirm and outline furtherdetails of how and when restrictions can be lted acrossScotland.It isthought thatMs Sturgeon will confirm changes scheduled to go ahead from Mayunder Level  of the framework - includingup to four people from two households socialising indoors, restaurants, cafeacutes, pubs and bars openingindoors until :, and cinemas, theatres, comedy clubs, amusement arcades and bingo halls reopening.It comes after the Covid- alert level in the UK was downgraded from Level  to Level  after a ldquoconsistent fall in cases, hospital admissions and deaths.The four chief medical officers of the UK put it downto the success of the vaccination programme and social distancing restrictions.This means that the epidemic is in general circulation, but transmission of the virus is no longer deemed to be high or rising exponentially.It comes as experts said that the nation is in a ldquostrong position to press ahead with the easing of coronavirus restrictions.Nicola Sturgeoned to work at Bute House in Edinburgh on Sunday after her election victory.She told the BBCrsquos The Andrew Marr Show she would be meeting clinical advisers over the next day.She added: ldquoWe have a Covid review on Tuesday where we will set out the final decisions for the next easing of restrictions scheduled for May .The country is due to move down from Level  to Level  of restrictions on this date.Up to four people from two households can socialise indoors in a private home in Level .Pubs can sell alcohol indoors and cinemas, theatres, comedy clubs, amusement arcades and bingo halls can open.However, there are still many areas still expected to remain closed in Level .Soft play, funfairs, indoor bowling, snooker pool halls and nightclubs are still not permitted to open in Level , according to current guidelines.Health authorities in the Moray are currently dealing with ldquouncontrolled, sustained community transmission of Covid-, with current restrictions failing to contain the spread.Latest statistics show Moray had . cases per , people in the seven days to May , signicantly higher than the rate in the rest of the country.Linda Bauld, professor of public health at the University of Edinburgh, warned that Moray may be in a dferent position from the rest of the country, with . cases per , in the seven days to May .She told BBC Good Morning Scotland: ldquoFrom what I understand from NHS Grampian colleagues this is not a specic outbreak as in a factory or another workplace, it is community transmission,  cases per ,, the R number is about . so people will recognise that meansyou have  people who are infected they could potentially pass it on to up to  so thatrsquos very serious.ldquoI think whatrsquos happened is wersquove still got a very transmissible virus, once you have clusters it does spread and it does seem to be in that local area, so I was particularly pleased to see two things ndash the first was opening of more testing sites in Moray and also giving good advice to people about the types of tests they can request based on symptoms or none, and the acceleration of that vaccine programme with invitations now being offered to younger adults more rapidly than where in Scotland.ldquoSo I really hope the situation stabilises. Only nine cases yesterday, letrsquos hope it continues to decline, otherwise there is a real risk that Moray will, as we feared, be one area which might have to delay its easing a little bit just at this crucial time when the rest of the country is moving into that next stage.The First Ministeris expected toaddress the nationjust after pm.Coverage will be screened live on theScottish Governments twitter account.It will also be broadcastlive on BBC One Scotland and iPlayer.

title: turning-tide-scotlands-waders
story: They are an iconic feature of our coastline and estuaries and their long-legged and long-billedsilhouettes appear too on lochsand lagoons, but the waders that are so much a part of our landscape are in dire trouble.In recent years populations of curlew and lapwing have collapsed, down % and % on what they once were, and oystercatchers too are struggling, with a third less of these beautul birds being recorded around our shores.Shting weather patterns and changing agricultural practices have been identied as some of the reasons why these birds are now failing to thrive but it is only in recent years that the full extent of the problem has been highlighted.Now urgent steps are being taken to reverse these population declines with Working for Waders, an initiative that brings together not just many dferent organisations and government bodies but also iniduals including farmers, crofters and land managers who all have a signicant role to play in turning the tide in favour of waders.Jessica Findlay is a Wildle Management Officer with NatureScot, one of the organisations involved in the initiative. She says that the last  years have seen numbers fall, with the most rapid declines being recorded in the last decade.ldquoNot everyone is aware of how badly populations have been affected, she says.ldquoIn some areas it still looks asthere are thousands of birds, while in other places they have all but disappeared.The first step to tackling the issue is raising awareness of the problem amongst those who can help to fix it and that means working with rural communities to change the timings of, amongst other things, grass cutting regimes.ldquoWithout the sort of cover that they get from long grass the birds are much more at risk from predators, says Jessica.Other steps include not rolling fields in spring, so that nests are not destroyed.Changing practices is not always straightforward but Jessica says she has been delighted by levels of engagement amongst farmers, including making lsquoscrapesrsquo ndash shallow ponds that are dug out by a digger and remain damp all year round, allowing insects to breed and offering feed for waders.Being able to offer small grants to help with this kind of work has proved to be very useful and other habitat management work includes cutting rushes and carrying out pest control.The public too, says Jessica, have a part to play by keeping dogs under control and Working for Waders is reinforcing the Access Code through promoting local signage that explains the breeding season of the birds and what dog owners can do to protect nests and chicks.ldquoOystercatchers, like all waders, nest on the ground which is why keeping dogs away from them during nesting time is so important.Some waders, including GoldenPlovers, make the journey to Scotland every summer, heading for moorlands to breed before flying back again before winter sets in.Redshanks, meanwhile, can be found around remote streams and wetlands, although these are getting harder to spot with their numbers declining % in  years.NatureScot, Scotlandrsquos Rural College, the RSPB, the British Trust for Ornithology, the James Hutton Institute, the Game and Wildle Conservation Trust and others have all joined forces in Working for Waders to put in place additional measures that they hope will help to improve the chances of the birds.This way of working follows the recently adopted Shared Approach to Wildle Management a collaborative model which brings all sorts of people together to develop action.Working for Waders is also open to ordinary members of the public to share their knowledge and enthusiasm to help tackle the decline of wading birds across Scotland. And the project, which was launched in , is continuing to capture the imagination of increasing numbers of people who have a shared interest in ensuring that the distinctive cry of the lapwing and the lonely call of the curlew donrsquot disappear from these shores.Just recently Working For Waders received a generous donation that allowed it to buy  trail cameras that are helping its members to understand the successes and failures of the waders across Scotland.These cameras have been distributed to farms across the country including the Isle of Skye, Speyside, Galloway and the Borders ndash all of them once home to large populations of waders.These cameras will be used to monitor what will hopefully be successful breeding seasons and help to inform watchers about the problems faced by these birds as part of a citizen science project that could make a positive impact on the future of some of Scotlandrsquos most important bird species.For more information visit: www.workingforwadersThis article is brought to you in association with NatureScot.

title: cabinet-office-minister-michael-gove-refuses-rule-legal-action-indyref2
story: The Cabinet Office minister, who is in Scotland this week, twice refused to give a straight answer on the point in a briefing with journalists.On Sunday, Mr Gove gave a series of ambiguous answers to the question on TV shows, saying he didnrsquot want to discuss the possibility of a Supreme Court challenge.Asked point blank todayhe was ruling out a challenge, he dismissed the issue as ldquotheorising and ldquoabstract debate and tried to change the subject, but did not deny it was a possibility.After the SNP won a landslide fourth term in last weekrsquos Holyrood election, Nicola Sturgeon said she would press ahead with Indyref when the Covid pandemic allowed.The First Minister has said she wants the vote by , thenindependence in .In a phone call with Mr Johnson on Sunday, she told the Prime Minister another referendum was now ldquoa matter of when not , despite his previous refusal to allow it.Asked about the FMs remark, Mr Gove said: ldquoOur focus is purely and principally on recovery at the moment. So of course there is a conversation about the constitution that some people will want to have.ldquoBut we think that is a distraction from the urgent need to make sure that we deal with backlog in NHS waiting lists, that we work together on economic recovery overall and that we also learn from each other when it comes to public sector recovery as well, whether it is in education or criminal justice.:Gordon Brown launches pro-Union campaign aimed at middle ScotlandThe Tory MP continued: ldquoPolitics is the language of priorities, our priority is to make sure we work with others on recovery at this moment.ldquoIt is not a conversation we believe is right to have at this moment, because it can only be a ersion of energy and attention at a time when there are far more pressing issues.Ms Sturgeon has said thatMr Johnson refuses to grant Holyrood the powers needed to hold a legally watertight referendum, the pro-independence parliament wouldpass its own Bill regardless, efectively daring Mr Johnson to challenge it at the UK Supreme Court.Asked specicallythe UK Government would take legal actionin such circumstances, Mr Gove would only say: ldquoIrsquom not getting into the whole question of court and litigation and all the rest of it, becausewe start theorising in the area then we are sucking oxygen out of the room when we should all be concentrating on recovery.ldquoOther people I am sure will want to speculate or theorise about these questions, but to my mind every second spent asking questions about the Supreme Court is a second wasted when it comes to concentrating on the issues in hand.:Scottish Tory leader Douglas Ross says SNPs proposed Indyref Bill is a non-starterPressed again for a yes or no answer, he said: ldquoAs I say, Irsquom not thinking about it. Irsquom not going there."Wersquore concentrating on recovery in the NHS, recovery in the economy, recovery in education, recovery in the criminal justice system. That is our focus.Mr Gove even refused to saya party ought todeliver its manesto pledgesit had the votes to do so.He was asked: ldquoIf a political party wins an election, does that give it a mandate to implement its manesto in government, provided it ghets the votes Mr Gove replied: ldquoI think all political parties will want to reflect at this time on the campaign thatrsquos just been run and the priorities that the public sent them to office to fulfil.ldquoI think the critical things is, as the First Minister herself said, her aim, her principal aim was to amke sure we had and effective recovery from Covid.ldquoNicola said, when yoursquore thinking who you should vote for, you should be thinking about which first minister you want to carry on with continuity of recovery work, and that was her principal message and of course we respect that.After it was pointed out that wasnrsquot an answer to the question, and it was put to him a second time, Mr Gove again failed to answer it.He said: ldquoIrsquom sure that the First Minister will put propositions to the Scottish Parliament and the Scottish Parliament will have a chance to reflect on any propositions she puts.ldquoBut I respect the fact that she said her focus was on the recovery and I think thatrsquos the right focus.Earlier, Deputy First Minister John Swinney said Indyref shoudl go ahead when coronavirus is suppressed and ldquostable.:Salmond says Alba is home for lost souls of the Yes movementHe told BBC Radio Scotland: ldquoWe judge it by a combination of things ndash the actions that wersquove got to take to suppress the prevalence of the virus, and to make sure that we are in a stable position.ldquoSecondly, that we are able to sustain that position to make sure that wersquove got the necessary infrastructure in place to ensure that the virus is suppressed.ldquoIf the pandemic meets those tests, then obviously we are able to consider the whole question of the timing of the referendum on independence.Scottish Tory leader Douglas Ross said the SNP should focus on the pandemic and delivering manesto pledges ldquowithin the remit of the Scottish Parliament, not Indyref.He said another referendum would create ldquouncertainty and ision all over again.

title: alex-salmonds-alba-party-spent-25-000-facebook-adverts----secured-no-holyrood-seats
story: Figures obtained by The Herald through Facebookrsquos Ad Library show the party spent pound, on  adverts in the  days prior to May .One internet campaigning expert has said that ldquoAlex Salmond basically poured his supporters money down Mark Zuckerbergs toilet.However, Albarsquos campaign manager Chris McEleny told The Herald that the partyrsquos strength was ldquoin the thousands of members that joined the party to campaign for independence.:Scottish Labour splash poundk on Facebook election ads mdash three times more than SNPThe targeted adverts included those urging people not to ldquowaste their vote, and instead ldquoMake your #ListVoteAlba and help secure the independence #SuperMajority.Commenting on the findings, internet political campaign expert Dr Rhys Crilley, part of the Department of Politics and International Relations at University of Glasgow, said it is ldquono surprise that some parties spent incredible amounts of money on Facebook ads in order to get their message across to voters.He added: ldquohellipAlba, who were confident that because they were pro-independence, they could take enough of the SNPs list vote to get seats in Holyrood, but their social conservatism and uninspiring vision for independence has no appeal with voters.ldquoBy spending pound, on Facebook ads and absolutely bombing in the polls, Alex Salmond basically poured his supporters money down Mark Zuckerbergs toilet.Responding to the figures, councillor Chris McEleny said: ldquoAlbarsquos strength was in the thousands of members that joined the party to campaign for Scottish independence.ldquoItrsquos no surprise that the Tories spent nearly as much as all the pro-independence parties combined.ldquoQuestions about where that money has come from have long been asked, whereas the independence movement thrives on the support of ordinary people across Scotland.ldquoAlthough social media is a medium that many people use, Scottish independence will be won by winning the hearts and minds of the people of Scotland by getting a campaign for independence up and running, not by topping a Facebook spend league table.Read the full breakdown of party Facebook campaign ad spending here.

title: scottish-election-labour-spent-190-000-election-adverts-three-times-snp-spending
story: Figures obtained through Facebookrsquos Ad Library show Scottish Labour splashed pound, promoting their own Facebook page through  adverts, with a further pound, promoting the Anas Sarwar page with  adverts in the  days prior to May .Posts included pleas from Gordon Brown, video endorsements from party members, and a repeated number of posts calling for the public to back Labour with their second vote.They gained  seats at the election, which equates to around pound spent per seat won.Those figures have been described as a ldquodisaster by the SNPrsquos Keith Brown, who also slated the ldquoultra-negative campaign of the Scottish Conservatives.However, Scottish Labour said they were, for the first time, ldquocompetitive digitally and are ldquobuilding a sophisticated operation towards being an alternative to the SNP.The Tories spent the second highest of all the parties on Facebook promotions ndash a total of pound, for  targeted ads.With their  seats ed, this works out at around pound, per seat.Meanwhile the SNP spent pound, on  ads on partyrsquos official page and just pound, on  posts on that of Nicola Sturgeon.:Alba Party spent pound, down Mark Zuckerbergs toilet as election ad spend revealedThe comparatively small spend for the nationalists, a total of pound,, works out at around pound for each of the  seats won.Keith Brown, the SNPrsquos campaign director, said: ldquoThese figures are a hammer blow for the Tories and their ultra-negative campaign - they are also a great endorsement of the SNPs digital communications strategy."Boris Johnson and Douglas Rosss party blasted double the cash that the SNP invested in digital ads and yet they won less than half of the number of seats that we did."The UK government will have spent a fortune on Twitter ads too - but people in Scotland are not daft and see right through all this Tory spin."This represents a disaster for Labour too, their combined Facebook spend is three times ours.ldquoFact is the SNPrsquos digital campaign was far more engaging than the rest and no other party can compete with our huge organic share rate.The Alba Party, whose leader Alex Salmond admitted early on during the counting that his party was unlikely to make a breakthrough, spent pound, on  promotions.Internet political campaign expert Dr Rhys Crilley, part of the Department of Politics and International Relations at University of Glasgow, said it is ldquono surprise that some parties spent incredible amounts of money on Facebook ads in order to get their message across to voters.He added: ldquoThe fact that Labour spent way more than any other party on Facebook ads yet had their worst performance ever in the history of the Scottish parliament demonstrates that throwing money at online advertising isnt an effective strategyyour policies and politicians dont appeal to the Scottish public.ldquoThe same can be said of Alba, who were confident that because they were pro-independence, they could take enough of the SNPs list vote to get seats in Holyrood, but their social conservatism and uninspiring vision for independence has no appeal with voters.ldquoBy spending pound, on Facebook ads and absolutely bombing in the polls, Alex Salmond basically poured his supporters money down Mark Zuckerbergs toilet.Dr Crilley said that with such a large membership base, the SNP ldquoprobably donrsquot have to rely on spending as much as other parties.He also pointed out that many of the SNP ads featured an endorsement from Line of Duty star Martin Compston ndash something that may perform better ldquowhen compared to other political ads which can often be pretty boring.Elsewhere, the Scottish Greens spent pound, on  ads, meanwhile the Scottish Lib Dems paid pound, on  posts.Commenting on the findings, a Scottish Labour spokesman said: ldquoFor the first time in recent political history Scottish Labour is competitive digitally.ldquoWersquore building a sophisticated operation as part of our journey towards building the alternative to the SNP.A spokesman for the Scottish Tories said: ldquoThe Scottish Conservatives fought this campaign on doorsteps, in the press and online.ldquoWe stopped an SNP majority, as we promised, and won our best ever result with an extra , votes than . For the second Holyrood election in a row, we have  MSPs and we have won more votes than ever before.ldquoWe were the only pro-UK party to improve our standing and we have cemented our place as Scotlandrsquos strongest and largest opposition party.And Alba Campaign Manager and Senior Councillor Chris McEleny said: ldquoAlbarsquos strength was in the thousands of members that joined the party to campaign for Scottish independence.ldquoItrsquos no surprise that the Tories spent nearly as much as all the pro-independence parties combined.ldquoQuestions about where that money has come from have long been asked, whereas the independence movement thrives on the support of ordinary people across Scotland.ldquoAlthough social media is a medium that many people use, Scottish independence will be won by winning the hearts and minds of the people of Scotland by getting a campaign for independence up and running, not by topping a Facebook spend league table.Commenting on the Scottish Greensrsquo figures, a spokesman said: ldquoThis election has seen the highest spend by all political parties since devolution began.ldquoThe Scottish Greens do not have wealthy corporate donors and instead rely on supporters and members, so it is no surprise that our overall spending on advertising has been dwarfed by the other parties.ldquoDespite this, the Scottish Greens grew our vote all across Scotland and were the only opposition party to make gains at this election.And a spokeswoman for the Scottish Lib Dems said: ldquoWe used a iety of campaign techniques, leaflets, doorstep conversations and online advertising.ldquoOur message got through to people in our strongest areas and we achieved record-breaking majorities.

title: andrew-mckie-can-starmer-save-labour
story: I donrsquot just mean that their ious schemes for improving efficiency, or equity, or some other supposedly desirable goal seldom work. We know that. Look at tax ndash reform of which is perennially the priority of both Leftand Right . After a couple of centuries of this, the UK has a tax code eight times longer than Agrave la recherche du temps perdu ndash  million words of it, none of which apply to the likes of Amazons Jeff Bezos.You may take that as an illustration that improving mattersis hard, because of unintended consequences, bureaucracy, the crooked timber of humanity, or some other excuse.You may, in fact, take the unsatisfactory nature of reality and general cussedness of things as a further indication that Something Must Be Done. If so, yoursquore probably just temperamentally political something ndash paradoxically ndash about which nothing can be done.:Andrew McKie: Is the conversion of political class to green issues all it seems But your average professional politician takes this a step further, with the kind of futile insistence on action that I mean. When it is crystal clear that not much can be done about a situation, they insist on doing something, anything, simply so that they can be seen to be taking action ndash asthat were, in itself, some sort of intrinsic good.Which brings me to Sir Keir Starmerrsquos exciting reshuffle of his shadow cabinet. Personally, I doubt that the message being sent by the people of Hartlepool was that they wouldnrsquot vote Labour until Nick Brown and Valerie Vaz had been sacked and Angela Rayner either demoted or promoted or both, depending on who you speak to.But evenSir Keirrsquos rejigging of his senior team had been better handled, more ambitious or extensive, or done something genuinely useful, such as expelling every member of Momentum, it would still have been a largely pointless course of action. Because the conclusion which anyone would draw from the English election results ndash and which, since he is not an idiot, I suspect Sir Keir himself has reached ndash is that there are no circumstances in which Labour can win an election in the foreseeable future.This doesnrsquot make all action a waste of time, but it makes it pretty well pointless for Sir Keir himself. He is in the unhappy position, similar to that of William Hague during Tony Blairrsquos first term in office, of being the leader of a party that stands no chance of ing to power until several things happen.William HagueThe first is that the party changes profoundly, the second is that the public forgets what it has been like recently, the third is that voters get fed up with the Conservatives ndash currently, whatever the view looks like in Scotland, in the happy position of being both popular and lucky ndash and the fourth is that the demographics of the entire country sht.The corresponding problems are that Labour currently has no idea how it ought to change: worse, large chunks of its membership remain unaware that it needs to and ndash again, rather like the Tories in the late s ndash think that they ought to be offering more of what has just been comprehensively rejected.That, of course, is an impediment to the public forgetting the electoral catastrophe that was Jeremy Corbynrsquos period as leader, especially when he was on the radio yesterday bizarrely claiming that Labourrsquos principal problem was Peter Mandelson. The third problem will, as with all governments, eventually solve itself, though as the examples of Margaret Thatcher and Tony Blair show, it can take a very long time and isnrsquot in any case something within Labourrsquos control. And the same is true, with knobs on, for the last point.The realignment of English voting, with the Tories picking up seats in the North and Labourrsquos gains coming exclusively in liberal, metropolitan seats, especially in London, has led some to speculate that there could simply be, over the next few years, a kind of reversal. The ldquoRed Wall of the North can be compensated for by Labour making inroads in a southern ldquoBlue Wall, according to these optimists, who have seized on the party gaining a few council seats in places like Worthing and Tunbridge Wells.The trouble is that the arithmetic doesnrsquot work. You canrsquot win an English election on metropolitan votes alone, partly because they are geographically concentrated. In fact, almost by definition, any vote heavily reliant on the young, graduates and cosmopolitan liberals is going to be concentrated.:What does Scottish Labours Anas Sarwar do next This is a psychological problem for Labour, too. Its most ardent supporters donrsquot know anyone like them, or who lives near them, who would dream of voting Tory, so they canrsquot imagine why anyone would. This makes it easy for them to conclude that they are morally superior, and that their opponents are wicked, selfish, racist or thick probably all of them.This is an unsatisfactory state of affairs because, even for those who donrsquot reflexively think the current Westminster government is doing badly or is ill-intended, it should be challenged robustly. This is true of all governments, of course, but Boris Johnsonrsquos freewheeling style makes it particularly necessary. But his is also a free-spending government, so Labourrsquos usual approach ndash spending more on public services ndash isnrsquot really an option.Though there is, as yet, little sign of Labour recovering here, the Scottish party may be in a better ndash or slightly less terrible ndash position than its counterpart south of the border. Anas Sarwar, just in the job, looks as though he could provide a personable and credible opposition, given a fair wind. Whether he does may matter to Labour at Westminster, because there is one caveat to my opinion about the arithmetic of English realignment, and itrsquos this: it doesnrsquot add up, unless you also have an awful lot of Scottish Labour MPs.Our columns are a  for writers to express their opinions. They do not necessarily represent the views of The Herald.

title: hopes-new-talent-rory-mcewens-former-cottage-transformed-artistic-residency
story: A much-loved folk musician and TV presenter, as well as a celebrated painter and sculptor, he produced a plethora of work in ious art forms.The Scot, born in Berwickshire in , is revered by many as an artistic genius and has inspired artists such as Van Morrison, The Animalsrsquo Eric Burdon, and Billy Connolly.And now it is hoped that he will continue to inspire a new tranche of talent as his former cottage studio is being transformed into an artistsrsquo residency.Family and friends of the painter gathered at Fogo Cottage, near Marchmont House, at Greenlaw in the Scottish Borders at the weekend for the unveiling of a plaque in his honour.Mr McEwenrsquos daughter, Samantha McEwen, said she and her three siblings are delighted that the cottage will once again be used as a creative space.ldquoMy main memory is of Rory setting the place up, she said. ldquoThe etching press and the wood burning stove from Sweden that he was completely delighted and obsessed with.ldquoThere was also the schoolhouse where he worked one summer. He hung tarpaulins from the ceiling. Those were years when he was exploring all sorts of new ideas.ldquoIt is truly wonderful that the cottages are being used again as studios. I feel, like my siblings, that Rory would have been really delighted by this inspired turn of events.The cottage is being restored as a creative space as part of a bigger project at Marchmont House led by former tech entrepreneur Hugo Burge.It will serve as a hub for artists and creative businesses.Mr McEwenrsquos other daughter, Christabel Holland, told of her memories of her fatherrsquos time at the site.ldquoRory first began making etchings when he was at Fogo and I remember the excitement of the huge and heavy press arriving, and the trays of acid which I found terrying, she said.ldquoHe showed me how you could use a feather to move the acid across a plate without it being eaten away.ldquoMy memories of the Fogo studio are all very happy ones the Manse was across the road and my siblings and I were encouraged to go and visit Rory at work. He even let us make etching plates of our own.ldquoI am thrilled that Hugo Burge has added the studio to the already thriving creative community at Marchmont, and cannot imagine a more appropriate use for it than to support and sustain present day artists and musicians.Mr McEwen began painting flowers at the age of eight, encouraged by his French governess.He went on to study at Eton and was taught art by Wilfrid Blunt, who was working on his seminal book The Art of Botanical Illustration.While he has dabbled in many art forms, it is his beautul, realist paintings of plants and flowers that Mr McEwen went on to become best known for.In the s, he began playing the -string guitar and in the following decade he and his brother Alex toured the US, recording Scottish songs and ballads and appearing on the Ed Sullivan Show twice.On ing to Britain, he became a regular face on the BBCrsquos Tonight show and regularly mixed with celebrities such as John Lennon.However, in the s, he gave up his musical career and decided to completely focus on art. His paintings can now be found in museums and collections worldwide.He continued working in London and Scotland until his death in  when, after being diagnosed with terminal cancer, he took his own le.On his paintings, he said: ldquoI paint flowers as a way of getting as close as possible to what I perceive as the truth, my truth of the time in which I live.Hugo Burge, director of Marchmont, said he hoped Mr McEwens cottage would prove to be a place of continued inspiration.He said: ldquoWersquore delighted to be able to honour the memory and achievements of someone who was not just a man of towering talent but who was so well-liked and had such generosity of spirit.ldquoI very much hope that Fogo will be an inspirational place for many more generations of artists.

title: european-countries-40-children-overweight
story: The World Health Organisationwarned that Covid- could potentially amply ldquoone of the most worrying trends in Europe.School closures and reduced access to meals and physical activity for children is likely to have widened inequalities, it said.Tam Fry, of the National Obesity Forum, said anecdotal evidence from clinics ldquoconfirmed European fears.: Scrap BMI, calorie labels and doctored adverts, MPs urgeA major report by the WHO looking at rates of childhood obesity in Europe found that Mediterranean countries had the highest rates.Data collected from , children aged six to nine in  countries found that % were overweight in Cyprus, Greece, Italy and Spain. Up to % of boys and % of girls in those countries were obese. However, children in Italy were more likely to eat fruit and vegetables daily than most other countries.Spain had the highest percentage of overweight boys - % of nine-year-olds were an unhealthy weight, followed by Greeceand Italy . Obesity amongst girls was highest in Cyprus at %.The lowest proportions of overweight children were observed in Asian countries such as Kyrgyzstan, Tajikistan and Turkmenistan, where % to % of boys and girls were overweight.Overweight and obesity stabilized or declined in some of the  European countries where it was possible to examine trends over time. Greece, Italy, Portugal and Spain, which all have the highest rates of obesity, as well as Slovenia showed a decreasing trend for both overweight and obesity.: The supermarkets most likely to nudge customers towards cut-price alcohol and junk foodSome of these countries implemented WHO-recommended measures to help tackle obesity rates, such as imposing taxes on sweetened beverages, food marketing restrictions and physical education classes.The UK did not take part in the study.Tam Fry of the National Obesity Forum said: ldquoTragically Scotland cannot be compared to the Mediterranean countries during the years under review.ldquoIt is the more alarming since because a scattering of reports from our clinics confirm the European fears that Covid- will increase our obesity figures.ldquoBecause we still have no working policy to tackle the problem, and Primary surveys have been not been possible during the pandemic for obvious reasons, no-one knows for sure by how much Scotlandrsquos statistics will have risen. ldquoBut when the figures are finally published, be prepared for a shock.": Mothers warning after suffering near fatal blood pressure complicationOn average, almost % of children had breakfast every day, around % ate fruit daily, and around % consumed vegetables daily.However, country-level figures for these healthy habits ied widely: daily consumption ranged from % to % for breakfast, from % to % for fruit, and from % to % for vegetables.Children with more educated parents were more likely to engage in sports dancing in most countries. However, children of less educated parents were more likely to walk or cycle to and from school.The WHO European Childhood Obesity Surveillance Initiativereport will bepresented at this weekrsquos European Congress on Obesity, which is being held online.

title: david-barnes-shouldnt-let-one-sore-irishman-ruin-pride-scotlands-lions
story: Bun fights over selection have become part of the tradition for the worldrsquos most famous touring team. However, the reaction from across the Irish Sea at having only eight players make the cut ndash with Johnny Sexton, James Ryan and Garry Ringrose amongst the omitted ndash was startlingly fierce.The fact that Scotland also have eight players on the trip was a particular source of angst, with former Irish forward turned outspoken pundit Neil Francis amusingly unhinged in his outrage.He claimed that he had detected a lsquosheepishnessrsquo about Gregor Townsend during an interview ahead of the grand reveal and asserted that this was clearly because the Scotsman had managed to bully or manipulate Lions head coach Warren Gatland into picking an unjustiable number of his countryman for the trip.Poor Warren! Who knew he was so malleable! ldquoNone of the Scottish players who have been included are starting Test standard, asserted Francis.ldquoGatland will not risk the whole Test series on the vagaries of some lunar alignment in Finn Russellrsquos head or how he feels when he gets out of bed on the day of the Test match, he snorted.ldquoBringing Duhan van der Merwe makes me sick to my stomach, he gasped.ldquoAli Price is the worst original selection pick at scrum-half for decades, he howled.Those are just the most colourful highlights. Stuart Hogg, Chris Harris, Rory Sutherland and Zander Fagerson were also targeted in an astonishing tirade. There wasnrsquot much in the way of analysis, but you canrsquot doubt the manrsquos passion!Former Ireland and Lions captain Brian OrsquoDriscoll was slightly more circumspect but his snfy take on Russell being selected ahead of Sexton was even more disappointing because it came from someone who we expect a bit more self-awareness and even-handedness from.ldquoWhen yoursquove got the Scottish head coach in Gregor Townsend in one corner, when yoursquore talking - decisions, of course hersquos going to be arguing for all of Finn Russellrsquos positive attributes, he said. ldquoThen you wait and look across and no-one is saying that about Johnny Sexton.This conveniently overlooks the fact that Gatland knows all about Sextonrsquos attributes, having started him at No. in five out of the last six Lions Tests over two tours, and naming him on the bench in the other. It also ignores the fact that Russell and Townsend have a chequered history, and while their relationship has been resurrected following that spectacular spat during the  Six Nations, the idea of the coach being tunnel visioned by the playerrsquos positive attributes to the exclusion of all  is patently ludicrous.In fairness, not all the wrath has been directed towards Scotland for having the temerity to match Irelandrsquos representation. Englandrsquos haul of  players, despite losing to all three of the other contributing countries during the recent Six Nations, has also gone down badly.While this disproportionate reaction from our Celtic cousins is a big relief because it proves that Scottish rugby does not have a monopoly on unjustied indignation, it does also highlight how important having a healthy representation on a Lions tour can be for a country, and wersquore not just talking about bragging rights here.The omission of players like -year-old Ryan and -year-old Ringrose is raw in Ireland because they know from previous experience that a tour such as this offers benefit which reaches beyond the inidual players involved.The self-belief, toughness and basic understanding of what is required to operate at the very highest level rubs off and it becomes a virtuous circle. In reality, eight players on the tour is not a disaster for Ireland, but they would much rather have  or  because the more players they have who have lived through the experience the wider the benefit reaches, and they would much rather their opponents didnrsquot have the same number getting that exposure.Over five successive tours during the last  years, Scotland have not had more than three players in an initial squad, which has undoubtedly left the national team and the two pro sides at a critical disadvantage when competing in high-class, big-pressure matches.Now, having eight players ndash plus two coaches ndash coming out of an environment where they have spent two months living, training, playing and hopefully winning alongside the best that Britain and Ireland have to offer, whilst taking on arguably the sportrsquos ultimate challenge, can have huge legacy benefits to the pro game in this country.Stuart Hogg, Finn Russell, Chris Harris, Duhan van der Merwe, Ali Price, Zander Fagerson, Rory Sutherland and Hamish Watson owe it to themselves ndash and they owe it to Scotland ndash to make the absolute most of this opportunity.Scotlandrsquos biggest ever Lionsrsquo representation was nine, when Finlay Calder led the touring side to a - series victory over Australia, and they won the Grand Slam the following year. The only previous time Scotland got eight onto a tour was in , just before the  Grand Slam success. Can history repeat itself in

title: covid-scotland-theatres-call-scottish-government-review-unviable-social-distancing-rules
story: Eleven theatres and performance art venues, including The Traverse Theatre, The Tron, The Festival Theatre, The Kings Theatre, Royal Lyceum Theatre Edinburgh and His Majestys Theatre in Aberdeensay an "urgent review" is needed -or  signicantly more public sector finance will be required to protect the already deeply damaged sector.:Outlanders Sam Heughan inspires fundraising duo to raise pound, for Lyceum TheatreWith the furlough scheme ending in September, many freelancers across the sector still excluded from support are desperate for work, and audiences have indicated they are "confident and keen to ", the Consortium has said.But they say the current two metrerequirement makes presenting and producing work "financially unviable" in "almost all contexts."A recent survey conducted by the Federation of Scottish Theatre showed that% of members believeit is "not economically viable for them to reopen while that level of social distancing is required."That includes  organisations across theand breadth of Scotland.In addition to the two metreguidance, theatre bosses have raised concerns regarding the lack of a "clear route-map" of when social distancing requirements might be lted- saying it is having a signicantly negative impact on the ability for venues to plan.In England theatres can open at % capacity from  May, with a plan for them toto full capacity from  June.However, Scotlandrsquos performing arts venues have said they urgently need the clarity of a route-map so they can plan accordingly - with many of Scotlands theatres reliant on touring productions that move across the UK.James Mackenzie-Blackman, Chief Executive of Eden Court Highlands  Chair of the Scottish Touring Theatre Consortium said while the consortium is grateful for government support thus far, more planning is needed for the months ahead.:Nicola Sturgeon set to confirm further lockdown easing mdash what to expect and how to watchHe said: ldquoThe Scottish Government has a proven track-record of understanding the value that the arts and culture bring to communities the -and-breadth of our country."The consortium is grateful for the intervention of the Cabinet Secretary, and for the reassurance from the First Minister that culture will play a critical role in the nationrsquos COVID recovery, but that will only be possiblewe are able to plan for the months ahead."We are a creative and professional sector, confident that we can safelyaudiences to our venues."We urge the government to recognise that the current guidance on social distancing makes a meaningful re-start of the sector almost impossible and to engage fully with the sector to address this.Fiona Sturgeon Shea, Chief Executive of the Federation of Scottish Theatre added: ldquoFST now represents a network of  professional performing arts organisations and iniduals throughout ScotlandldquoEvery part of that network has been damaged by the impact of COVID, yet is keen and poised to move forward to recovery. We have worked carefully and collaboratively to ensure that the sector is ready to begin making, producing and presenting work for public audiences and participants in as safe and accessible a way as possible.ldquoWith the right regulations, and package of support, the sector will be able to continue making its signicant contribution to the cultural, social and economic le of Scotland, as well as health and wellbeing, as part of its recovery and beyond.The Scottish Theatre Producing Consortium is made up of the following nationwide venues:All Consortium members are also part of the Federation of Scottish Theatre, Scotlandrsquos membership and development body for professional dance, opera and theatre.A spokesperson for the Scottish Government said: "A new administration is in the process of being formed and the First Minister has been clear the focus will be on recovery from all aspects of the pandemic."The First Minister will provide an update on the latest steps out of lockdown on Tuesday.

title: covid-scotland-nicola-sturgeon-to-ease-restrictions
story: The First Minister said she had been back at her desk after last weekrsquos SNP victory in the Holyrood elections, consulting with clinical advisers about the ldquonext steps as we gradually hope tothe country to something much more like normality.With coronavirus numbers having fallen, and the continued rollout of the vaccination programme, Ms Sturgeon had previously indicated Scotland could move to Level  restrictions from Monday May .However in Moray, which has the highest number of coronavirus cases in Scotland, public health bosses have said it is ldquoentirely possible that the area will not be able to see restrictions eased to this level.NHS Grampian deputy director of public health Chris Littlejohn said the situation in the area ldquoremains of great concern.:Nicola Sturgeon lockdown update mdash how to watch and what to expectMoving to Level  under the Scottish Governmentrsquos five-tier system would mean that friends and family could meet inside houses, with gatherings involving up to four people from no more than two households permitted.The vacination programme is helping drive down infectionsPubs and restaurants would also be allowed to serve alcohol indoors in Level , while cinemas, theatres, concert halls, music venues, comedy clubs, amusement arcades and bingo halls would all be allowed to reopen ndash although soft play centres, funfairs, bowling alleys, snooker and pool halls and nightclubs would still have to remain closed.On Monday, Boris Johnson confirmed people in England will be able to hug loved ones, dine in restaurants and go on holiday abroad from May .Earlier in the day the national Covid- alert level was downgraded after a ldquoconsistent fall in cases, hospital admissions and deaths, with the four chief medical officers of the UK, including Scotlandrsquos Dr Gregor Smith, saying the threat level should be reduced thanks to the success of the vaccination programme and social distancing restrictions.Speaking ahead of her latest coronavirus update, Ms Sturgeon stressed the need to ldquoremain vigilant to ensure virus levels do not increase again.And she said her Government was also beginning the task of ldquosecuring a fair and sustainable recovery from the pandemic.The First Minister stated: ldquoContinuing the fight against Covid and guiding the country safely through the rest of the pandemic is my number one priority.ldquoSince the election, I have been back at my desk, consulting with clinical advisers on our next steps as we gradually hope tothe country to something much more like normality.ldquoToday we will outline those latest steps in lting restrictions, while also making clear that we need to remain vigilant against any resurgence in Covid levels across Scotland.:Testing ramped up in Grantown-on-Spey after cluster of Covid casesldquoWith the renewed mandate we have been given by the people of Scotland, I will this week also start to take forward our agenda, starting with our commitments for the first  days as we begin the task of securing a fair and sustainable recovery from the pandemic.ldquoThat includes taking forward an NHS recovery plan, taking the first steps to establish a National Care Service, getting additional financial support to businesses and investment to recruit more teachers and classroom assistants.ldquoThe people of Scotland voted for a serious Government for serious times ndash and with this re-elected SNP administration, in a historic fourth consecutive term in office, that is exactly what they will get.

title: partys-facebook-election-spend-says-priorities
story: In this ldquopandemic election, when door-to-door canvassing and in-person meetings were signicantly restricted, social media communication, including but not limited to advertising, was ndash besides televised debates ndash the most important tool for political parties to get their messages across and persuade the electorate to vote for them.Social media advertising represents an important add-on in a wider context of persuasive communication during political campaigning, but it is unlikely to be decisive.We, therefore, have to be careful when interpreting social media advertising spending in relation to the electoral success.However, data on how much political parties in Scotland spent on Facebook ads reveals some interesting insights.It confirms that the partiesrsquo stance on the constitutional question in relation to the Scottish independence , political performance and track record rather than social media budget played a decisive role when people were casting their ballots.:Labour spent pound, on election adverts, three times SNP spendingOut of the three largest parties in the ScottishParliament, the SNP and Nicola Sturgeon spent the least on Facebook adswith the Scottish Labour being a record spender , followed by the Scottish Conservatives . Yet the SNP had the highest efficiency per seat won.They had a very strong start at the beginning of the election campaign and additionally capitalised on excellent leadership and communication of the First Minister during the pandemic.Their messages emphasising competent leadership of Nicola Sturgeon and democratic argument for the second independence referendum after the COVID- recovery were cleverly chosen and boded well with the Scottish electorate.The fact that the Scottish Labour and Anas Sarwar were the highest spenders indicates their ambition to become the biggest opposition party. Anas Sarwar is considered as one of the most talented leaders in the Labour Party, not just in Scotland, but UK-wide, yet his persistent distancing from the constitutional debate did not seem to convince the voters.The Labour focused on COVID recovery instead, but orcing the recovery from the constitutional question is like discussing the issue without a backdrop. The constitutional question matters to people of Scotland on both sides of the debate, so it is unsurprising that their advertising spending did not translate into an electoral success.The Scottish Conservatives were campaigning on a single issue ndash opposing the second referendum ndash and came across as the most convincing amongst the pro-union parties. Their relatively high spending figure indicates how important this election was for the future of the United Kingdom and their investment was the second most efficient after the SNP.The Liberal Democrats found themselves in a conundrum. They pose as a pro-EU party, even though Willie Rennie during televised debates showed an astonishing lack of knowledge and understanding of the EU, evident in incorrect statements on how old the EU is and misguided comparisons between the EU and the UK. Lib Dems also lack clear policies on what this pro-European stance means, while reducing the constitutional argument to a simple ldquowe do not need another isive referendum. It is unsurprising that their spending of pound, was the least efficient per seat won .:Alba Party spent pound, down Mark Zuckerbergs toilet as election ad spend revealedFollowing the Liberal Democrats were the Scottish Greens with pound, spent on Facebook ads, indicating their hopes to increase the representation in the Scottish Parliament, which they did with a reasonable efficiency. They came across as a very consistent and competent party in this election and their pro-independence arguments were at times more eloquent and convincing than the SNPrsquos.The increasing societal concern about climate emergency, particularly in the light of post-COVID recovery, also played in their favour.Albarsquos spending was the lowest and the most fruitless. The party had a slim chance in this election, considering it was only founded three months before the election with manesto launched a few weeks before the polling day and tainted by allegations against its leader Alex Salmond.Social media without a doubt played a very important part in this election, but there is a question to what extent Facebook advertising had an effect beyond ldquopreaching to the converted.Where social media will play a far more important role is cultivating the future political debates in Scotland. We need to move away from clicheacutes of ldquoisive referendums and ldquouniting the country. Referendums do not need to be isivewe learn to listen to each other, debate with respect and discuss issues that matter in a constructive manner. There is no progress without dferences in opinions, so we need to come to terms with ersity of views and cultivate a constructive democratic dialogue amongst politicians and the electorate alike. Social media will be one of the central s for this.Dr Alenka Jelen is a Senior Lecturer Communications, Media and Culture at the University of Stirling.

title: cookie policy
story: Cookie PolicyWhat Are CookiesAs is common practice with almost all professional websites this site uses cookies, which are tiny files that are downloaded to your computer, to improve your experience. This page describes what information they gather, how we use it and why we sometimes need to store these cookies. We will also share how you can prevent these cookies from being stored however this may downgrade or #break# certain elements of the sites ality.For more general information on cookies see the Wikipedia article on HTTP Cookies.How We Use CookiesWe use cookies for a iety of reasons detailed below. Unfortunately in most cases there are no industry standard options for disabling cookies without completely disabling the ality and features they add to this site. It is recommended that you leave on all cookiesyou are not sure whether you need them or not in case they are used to provide a service that you use.Disabling CookiesYou can prevent the setting of cookies by adjusting the settings on your browser . Be aware that disabling cookies will affect the ality of this and many other websites that you visit. Disabling cookies will usually result in also disabling certain ality and features of the this site. Therefore it is recommended that you do not disable cookies.The Cookies We SetWe use cookies when you are logged in so that we can remember this fact. This prevents you from having to log in every single time you visit a new page. These cookies are typically removed or cleared when you log out to ensure that you can only access restricted features and areas when logged in.From time to time we offer user surveys and questionnaires to provide you with interesting insights, helpful tools, or to understand our user base more accurately. These surveys may use cookies to remember who has already taken part in a survey or to provide you with accurate results after you change pages.When you submit data to through a form such as those found on contact pages or comment forms cookies may be set to remember your user details for future correspondence.In order to provide you with a great experience on this site we provide the ality to set your preferences for how this site runs when you use it. In order to remember your preferences we need to set cookies so that this information can be called whenever you interact with a page is affected by your preferences.Third Party CookiesIn some special cases we also use cookies provided by trusted third parties. The following section details which third party cookies you might encounter through this site.This site uses Google Analytics which is one of the most widespread and trusted analytics solution on the web for helping us to understand how you use the site and ways that we can improve your experience. These cookies may track things such as how long you spend on the site and the pages that you visit so we can continue to produce engaging content.For more information on Google Analytics cookies, see the official Google Analytics page.Third party analytics are used to track and measure usage of this site so that we can continue to produce engaging content. These cookies may track things such as how long you spend on the site or pages you visit which helps us to understand how we can improve the site for you.The Google AdSense service we use to serve advertising uses a DoubleClick cookie to serve more relevant ads across the web and limit the number of times that a given ad is shown to you.For more information on Google AdSense see the official Google AdSense privacy FAQ.More InformationHopefully that has claried things for you and as was previously mentionedthere is something that you aren#t sure whether you need or not it#s usually safer to leave cookies enabled in case it does interact with one of the features you use on our site.Howeveryou are still looking for more information then you can contact us through one of our preferred contact methods.Email: support@orcadianPhone:  copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. Reg No. – SC Registered Office: Hell’s Half Acre, Hatston, Kirkwall, Orkney, KW GJ

title: covid 19 vaccinations open for 18 to 29 year olds
story: coronavirusCOVID- vaccinations to open for  to -year-oldsMay ,  at : pmNHS Orkney has today confirmed that those aged  to  will be offered their first COVID- vaccination appointments at The Balfour, starting this month.The dates for these will be Saturday, May  Sunday, May  and Saturday, June . Letters will be sent out to these patients in the week commencing Monday, May  detailing when to attend for their vaccine.Letters are also being sent out this week to all patients aged  to  who have not yet had a first vaccine, inviting them to phone the vaccination centre to book in for this. The telephone number for the vaccination centre is   .Maureen Firth, NHS Orkney head of primacy care services, said: #We will be sending out further letters towards the end of next week to all patients who attended the Pickaquoy Centre for their first vaccine.#These letters will detail where patients should go to get their second vaccine. These vaccines will be given at the Balfour and the Kirkwall Vaccination Centre so, please read your letter carefully to know where to go.Ms Firth also revealed that: #we are due to vaccinate in the region of , patients during May. #We would therefore please ask that you attend at the time you are given unless you have an urgent reason to ask for this to be rescheduled. This will make our logistics and planning so much easier.#Thank you so much for your support during this vaccination programme, it has been much appreciated.”copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: feline finds fame after election count invasion
story: The owner of a cat who had to be ejected from the Orkney election count has shared her surprise after her favourite found national fame.Hannah Ker from Kirkwall was in stitches after spotting footage of her tortoiseshell Lola on both local and national news.The moggy made a surprise entrance at the Pickaquoy Centre arena, this morning, much to the amusement of count staff.After a quick wander to check that counting procedures were up to scratch, Lola was soon escorted from the premises.It wasn’t long before footage of the cat’s unexpected visit appeared on the national news, amid more standard coverage of the elections. Other news outlets soon picked up the story, while local commentators suggested that the cat might make a “purrrfect” late entry candidate.“We often wonder what Lola gets up to when we are working so we couldn’t believe our surprise when we seen her on the national news,” Miss Ker told The Orcadian.”She has always been such a friendly cat so it was no surprise she was away making new friends.“We always knew our little Lola would be destined for big things.”copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: highlands and islands list msps declared
story: electionHighlands and Islands list MSPs declaredMay ,  at : pm vw, px"  Four Conservatives will represent the Highlands and Islands region in the Scottish Parliament, alongside one MSPs each from the SNP, the Greens and Labour.The result for the region was officially declared this afternoon, Saturday.MSPs elected to the Highlands and Islands region include Scottish Conservative and Unionist Party leader Douglas Ross. He will be joined by his tory colleagues Edward Mountain, Donald Cameron and Jamie Halcro Johnston.Mr Halcro Johnston, who hails from Orkney, was one of four Highlands and Islands list MSPs ed to their seat in this election.Representing the SNP for the Highlands and Islands will be Emma Roddick, while Rhoda Grant has been ed to her seat as a Labour MSP. Ariane Burgess will represent the region for the Scottish Green Party.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: navy divers to receive freedom of orkney honour
story: newsNavy ers to receive Freedom of Orkney honourMay ,  at : pm vw, px"  The Royal Navy Northern Diving Group will have the Freedom of Orkney bestowed upon them in recognition of the group#s historic connection in commemorating those lost in the sinking of the HMS Royal Oak.Every year, the ers change the White Ensign on the wreck of the Royal Oak which was torpedoed while at anchor in Scapa Flow on October , , with the loss of  lives.Due to COVID restrictions,  was the first year since the recovery of the ship#s bell in  that the northern ing group was not able to change the White Ensign and pay tribute to those who lost their lives.The group and its predecessors have also assisted in disposing of historic ordinances such as mines, torpedoes and grenades on  occasions, and have assisted authorities in a wide range of commemorations and events over the years.Those who have also received the Freedom of Orkney include artist Stanley Cursiter, writer Ernest Marwick, navy ship HMS Orkney, the Queen#s Own Highlanders, and most recently Dr John Rae.At a meeting of the full council today , Orkney Islands Council councillors approved to confer the honour upon the ing group.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. Reg No. – SC Registered Office: Hell’s Half Acre, Hatston, Kirkwall, Orkney, KW GJ

title: recovery is the number one priority for re elected orkney msp
story: Liam McArthur has said that Orkney#s recovery from the fallout of the COVID- pandemic will be his number one priority as he enters a new Scottish Parliamentary term.Mr McArthur told The Orcadian that he was delighted to retained his seat in Orkney, which he has served for the past  years.Asked about his key hopes for the next five years, the Scottish Liberal Democrat MSP said: #I think the unying thing I would like to see for Orkney, the Highlands and Islands and Scotland is a focus on recovery. That recovery will be dferent in dferent parts of the country.#I#ve said consistently throughout this campaign — and what Willie Rennie has been saying nationally — is that that focus on recovery has to be the number one priority.#Mr McArthur was ed to his seat with , of , votes.SNP candidate Robert Leslie came second in the race with a total of , votes.Sam Bown, of the Scottish Conservative and Unionist Party received  votes.Scottish Labour candidate, Coilla Drake, gained  votes.copy The Orcadian - A ision of Orkney Media Group Ltd Co. title: nine-year-old-dubai-dj-scratches-way-fame-world-contest
story: Data ed from the Piano meterActive meterExpired callback event.As a subscriber, you are shown % less display advertising when reading our articles.Those ads you do see are predominantly from local businesses promoting local services. These adverts enable local businesses to get in front of their target audience – the local community.It is important that we continue to promote these adverts as our local businesses need as much support as possible during these challenging times.Michelle Rasul in the lobby of her apartment building in Dubai, United Arab EmiratesA nine-year-old girl who lives in Dubai is scratching her way to the top as a DJ in world competitions.Michelle Rasul was already spinning turntables, scratching hip-hop records and making the beats drop four years ago, when she was just learning how to read and write.Four years later, she is one of the worldrsquos top DJs and competed in this yearrsquos global championship.At her home in the skyscraper-studded city of Dubai, the turntable whiz from Azerbaijan nodded her baseball cap-adorned head to the beat and showed off her skills scratching, cutting and fading. vw,vw,px, px"Michelle Rasul enjoys scratching her turntable in the lobby of her apartment building in Dubai Her tiny fingers flew across the turntable as she created a sizzling landscape of electric audio effects and recalled how she got her start as a child turntable celebrity ndash which, in fact, was not all that long ago.ldquoI looked at my dad while he was practising DJ-ing and I saw him and was like, lsquoWow, is he doing magic or something  Hersquos a real magician, bro!rsquo Michelle told the Associated Press, bubbling with enthusiasm.ldquoWhen I turned five, on my birthday, I told him, lsquoDad, I want to be a world famous DJ. Irsquom going to start practisingrsquo.As though recounting a decades-long career, she grinned and added: ldquoAnd the rest is history. vw,vw,px, px"Michelle Rasul chases a friendrsquos dog at a park near her house Michelle, the youngest-ever contestant in the DMC World DJ Championship, ranked th out of  DJ stars from around the world in the Portablist category this year, the global portable scratch competition.The  competition was held online due to the coronavirus pandemic.Although she did not advance to the next round this time, she is determined to beat her father, Vag ldquoDJ Shock Rasulov, a professional who taught her the tricks of the trade and was ninth this year, in next yearrsquos competition.ldquoI love competing in battles, I just love DJ-ing, she said.ldquoItrsquos my passion. vw,vw,px, px"Michelle Rasul scratching her turntable Turntabling, which burst on to the music scene from hip-hop artists in the late s, can look like a basic act ndash taking a record, putting the needle down and sliding it back and forth with onersquos fingertips.But for the wizards, it is an art form, involving spontaneous sound mixing and advanced techniques like quick, rhythmic scratches and ldquocrabs, rubbing the record under the needle.From the moment her parents gave her a mini DJ starter kit, they recognised her extraordinary abilities.Even as a baby, she was fascinated and would punch all the buttons on her fatherrsquos equipment.ldquoShe just catches things so fast, said her mother Sadia Rasulova, a former violinist who also encouraged Michellersquos love of music. vw,vw,px, px"Michelle Rasul playing the piano ldquoI realised that shersquos a star, that shersquos really talented.When her peers were listening to nursery rhymes, or as she put it, ldquoBaby Shark stuff or ABC songs, Michelle said she was hooked on rap legends such as Tupac Shakur, Chuck D, Jay-Z, the Notorious B.I.G. and Michael Jackson, who remains her favourite.Her parents started posting footage of her scratching online, and Michellersquos popularity exploded.Her Instagram account and persona as the self-described ldquoyoungest DJ in the world has racked up , followers.Online messages from aspiring DJs aged six to  poured in from around the globe, she said. vw,vw,px, px"Michelle Rasul jumps around in the lobby of her apartment Michellersquos feed is populated with posts of her breakdancing and scratching furiously alongside her sunglasses-sporting father, spinning hip-hop and techno tunes live for her listeners, strumming the bass in her free time and playing at events such as Dubairsquos recent food festival.Before the pandemic put big gatherings on hold, Michelle performed regularly at weddings, parties and music festivals across the city.While the rest of the world is focused on her accomplishments as a DJ star, Michelle is busy bouncing through le, attending online school, skateboarding, reading and hanging out with friends and dogs at her neighbourhood park.But her heart is always in her turntabling.ldquoI canrsquot imagine my le without music, she said.ldquoLike from the start, from the very beginning, when I was really little.copy -. title: tall ships look set to return in 2023 as lerwick wins host race
story: Lerwick is understood to have won its bid to be a host port for the Tall Ships Race  – providing a massive tourism and economic boost to the isles.The popular sailing event – previously held in Shetland in  and  – would bring with it thousands of sailors and tourists to the islands.The timing of the event will be even more signicant as the isles, like where across the country, has suffered economically from the Covid crisis.In , when the massive flotilla of ships last visited, the event generated nearly £. million for the local economy and attracted around , visitors. has seen a confidential letter to councillors from chief executive Maggie Sandison confirming that Shetland had won its bid.In the letter she stated: “It is clearly positive news that we’ve secured the event which will be a very welcome boost to our community after lockdowns, restrictions and so many community events being cancelled.#Lerwick will be a host port along with Hartlepool, Liverpool, Fredrikstad in Norway, and Den Helder in the Netherlands.All I remember from  was everything was alcohol related with very little for families...The overall turnout for the  Scottish election is  per cent, according to Shetland Islands Council. That is similar to the  by-election, which#Polling stations across Shetland opened at am this morningfor the Scottish parliamentary elections. Thirty-four polling stations will be open until pm#The SIC says it has taken steps to make polling stations as safe as possible as final preparations are made for Thursday#s Scottish elections. title: port looking ahead to better times having weathered worst of pandemic
story: Harbour traffic statistics have again highlighted the severe impact of the pandemic ndashthough bosses are working towards ldquobetter times ahead.The latest Lerrwick Port Authority figures for the first quarter of  show a decline in all sectors compared to the same period pre-lockdown.They are said to show the continuing severe effects Covid- and the oil industry slump on Shetlandrsquos economy.#The coming months should bring slight improvements in activity on the long haul to recovery.Vessel tonnage for the period, at ,, gross tonnes, dropped  per cent.shipping and an  percent decrease in fishing boats.Cargo was down per centat , tonnes, including drops of  per centin oil-related shipmentsand  per cent in roll-on roll-off ferry freight.Ferry passengers travelling between Lerwick, Aberdeen and Kirkwall, fell  per centto ,during the three months, due mainly to national lock-down during the period.There were no cruise ship passengers during the quarter which usually sees a gradual start to the season ndash yet to begin.The , boxes of whitefish landed at Lerwick fish market was downdown  per cent.In the pelagic sector, mackerel throughput fell  per cent.Capt. Grains added: ldquoThe UK governmentrsquos decision to allow cruise ships into English ports from th May will hopefully be followed soon by the Scottish government enabling resumption, giving us a part-season and helping rebuild Shetlandrsquos hard-hit tourism industry.ldquoThe recent opening up of UK internal travel should benefit ferry traffic and visiting pleasure craft.ldquoWhitefish landings have been showing signs of recovery and port-Brexit movement of seafood exports through the EU is slowly improving.ldquoThe offshore decommissioning market is promising and support for the renewable energy sector continues to increase...Ive been a reporter since  at newspapers in Lincolnshire and East Anglia. Before joining The Shetland Times, I was part of Archants Investigations Unit, reporting for titles across the group. When not at work, Im usually reading books, listening to records or walking around the countryside.Restore Scotland candidate Brian Nugent has criticised the First Minister#s comments on a fishing deal, which he claimed #betrayed a lack of knowledge# on theFishermen in Shetland today welcomed the rejection of a deal with Norway.The death of a Shetland fisherman has been highlighted in a new campaign on man overboard protection at sea.Seas near Shetland are reported to be teeming with oil-eating bacteria, which scientists say could help deal with future oil spills.Lerwick Port Authority has received a share of £. million towards work at the harbour.A seafood organisation has warned the Brexit red tape seen earlier this year could be the demise of small fishing businesses.
