title: council confirms tall ships to return in 2023
story: The SIC has confirmed long-awaited news that the Tall Ships Races willto Shetland in .Lerwick is one of four confirmed host ports for the races, which were last in the isles in ., after a letter from chief executive Maggie Sandison to councillors confirmed Lerwick had been selected.Council leader Steven Coutts said the news was #tremendous# for Shetland.LPA chief executive Calum Grains said the news was particularly welcome in a time of Covid recovery.#The colourful visit will provide a major event for the community, a showcase for island products and culture, a boost for the economy and enhance Lerwick’s international reputation as a tall ships-friendly port.#..Twelve young Shetlanders will take part in the Tall Ships Races  which set off from Aalborg in Denmark next month.Almost £ million of council money has been allocated to hosting the  Tall Ships Races in Shetland, which the SIC hopes will be a#THE FIRST leg of this year’s Tall Ships Races ended in Måløy last weekend with five young Shetlanders aboard the first-placed Class A ship Christian#Already a subscriber  Log in below. mailing list to get one daily email update at midday on whats happening in Shetland.

title: london developer wants to build 16 family homes on
story: An Tìr, An Cànan, ‘S na DaoineCharles Garton Jones, a London-based property developer who also owns the Cow Shed boutique bunkhouse in Uig, is aiming to build the detached houses next to his Bracken Hide Hotel, off Struan Road. he hopes to provide the homes with an ultrafast broadband connection free of charge for the first five years.He said: “We have applied for  three-bedroom houses, and five four-bedroom houses. They are all on generous plots with good-sized gardens. The site is circa five acres, so we are looking at about three houses per acre.“The houses are entirely within the local plan site which is allocated for housing with an indicative housing capacity of  houses.”When asked what his motivation was for building, he said: “I think Skye post-pandemic is a good market for detached houses, but what we are trying to do is build homes with accessibility to schools and Portree itself.” sought to establish how much the homes would actually cost.Mr Garton Jones said: “We haven#t got that far. Simply because until you have planning permission you don’t have a product.“And the market moves, so a figure now could be out of date in six month’s time. I have been encouraged, though, by the new five per cent deposit mortgages the government are backing. I hope that could be really helpful.“Lenders are also starting to offer mortgages at five and a half times buyers’ earnings as opposed to four or four and a half times, so that will also help with how much people can borrow.”He added: “Because of the proximity to the schools and Portree it is not going to appeal to people who are looking to buy a holiday home. They want to be in the middle of nowhere.“I think it is going to appeal to people who are looking to buy it as their main home and want access to the schools and decent internet so they can work.”As an extra incentive the developer plans to connect all the houses via a full fibre GB broadband connection to the nearby BT exchange.“This connection will be provided by us completely free of charge for the first five years,” he added.“This is possible because the capacity we will have for the hotel is well beyond what we will need. This is still subject to BT surveys, though, but it is a realistic aspiration.”The housing scheme, which Mr Garton Jones describes as “an amalgam of Highland and Scandinavian culture” has been designed by Plockton-based architect Olli Blair, who caught the eye of the developer with his work on the Raasay Distillery building.Mr Garton Jones said he hoped to get on site by September October this year.The Bracken Hide Hotel is scheduled to open in April .If anyone is looking for more information on the homes or to register an interest they can contact Mr Garton Jones via charlie@gartonjones

title: waternish youngsters raise more than 7000 with
story: An Tìr, An Cànan, ‘S na DaoinePat Matheson from Halistra lost her husband Campbell to the illness, and her family thought it would be a good idea to raise funds for the charity in memory of Campbell and to raise awareness of AMMF. The family would like to extend their gratitude to everyone who helped achieve the remarkable sum in excess of £,.SomhairleRuairidhLexyAbigailRoganEoghainnMaraand Tobihad aimed to cycle a total of  miles to raise funds for AMMF. But on Saturday the th of March, which would have been their Seanair’s birthday, most of them cycled from Fairy Bridge to their Granny’s house and smashed their target – clocking up over  miles between them in high winds, rain, sleet and hailstones.

title: lifeboat mission leaves portree crew member in a
story: An Tìr, An Cànan, ‘S na DaoineRNLI volunteers have been sharing some of the stranger situations they have found themselves in when their pagers go off to herald the lesaving charity’s Mayday Mile appeal.Iain Beaton, a member of Portree leboat, was enjoying that post-lockdown highlight, a trip to the hairdresser, when his pager sounded one day last summer.Iain, a builder who has  years’ leboat service in two separate stints, said: “I hadn’t had a haircut in months and I was desperately looking forward to it. I had not long sat down in the salon in Portree and was getting my hair washed when my pager went off.“I just sprinted out the door with the cape still on and my head full of shampoo – you don’t think when you get a shout, you just go. Morven the hairdresser didn’t know what had happened and I certainly got a lot of funny looks running down the pier!“We went to the aid of two women who had got cut off by the tide at the back of Raasay, and they kept looking at me. Needless to say I got endless ribbing from the crew. I’m just glad Morven hadn’t started cutting or I would have looked even stranger. Morven came up to the house the next day so I did eventually get that haircut.”The RNLI is preparing for a busy summer with more families than ever expected to opt for holidays in the UK because of the pandemic. Many of them will be heading to the coast.To keep lesavers kitted out and trained it has launched the Mayday Mile which encourages folk to cover a one-mile distance, be it walking, running, swimming, skating or cycling, to help raise funds. and find out how to make a donation or hold a socially-distanced sponsored event.

title: editorial kennedy commitment would be a fitting cause for political
story: An Tìr, An Cànan, ‘S na DaoineIt was his seventh in a row as a Highland member of parliament and with a majority of more than , in Ross, Skye and Lochaber it seemed then that his seat was secure for as long as he wanted it.Yeta week is a long time in politics, the last decade has proved aeonic.The General Election of May  brought an end to the UK’s  years of centre-left dominance, and it was to prove the first in a series of seismic polls which tore up the psephologist’s rule book.The  election gave the Liberal Democrats a taste of power in an unlikely coalition with the Tories, but it has been electoral oblivion for them ever since – including in their former Highland heartlands.A year later the SNP romped to a majority in a Scottish parliament that had been designed to prevent any one party having overall control. In so doing the path was paved toward an independence referendum which eventually maintained the -year-old Union, but still served to elevate the question to become the defining Scottish issue of our times.– was Charles Kennedy’s.A few weeks later the affable Abrach was dead, aged just .The turbulent, and increasingly polarised times continued as a Brexit referendum was granted, and the UK – in spite of all major parties backing remain – voted to leave the EU in . There followed four years of painful negotiation Theresa May was anointed, became a lame duck, and departed as PM to be replaced by Boris Johnson.Johnson saw off Jeremy Corbyn and ‘got Brexit done’ as he said he would, but post-Covid he might yet be done for himself. As rumours rage that in preference to lockdown he said he would tolerate a virus # from which he almost died # spreading so severely that bodies could “pile high on the streets”, there is a growing sense that the public reckoning he has long escaped may finally be in sight.Meanwhile in Scotland, having survived the ugly fall-out from of an investigation into the handling of sexual harassment complaints against her predecessor and political mentor Alex Salmond, Nicola Sturgeon remains odds-on to become First Minister again in  # perhaps even with the overall majority she was unable to secure in .Whether victory leads to a second referendum depends not only on next week’s result but on whose ‘rights’ will take precedence in the eyes of the UK government who by law would need to sanction another vote.Because inescapably it is Covid-, how it is tackled and treated, and how we can recover as a country from it, that is the major issue facing all of us.It seems lamentable that, amid the constitutional flux and an increasing entrenchment of views, that there has been so little sign of a consensual approach – between both governments and parties # to steer the country away from the crisis.And that brings us back to the original point about the late Charles Kennedy.The landscape which he occupied has altered beyond recognition, but has changed politics meant better politics or brought improved outcomes  The jury is out, and it is a question voters should consider as they head for the booths.’ brought some encouraging news.Having seen the treatment Mr Kennedy received back in , the LibDems have called for a “a zero-tolerance approach to abuse and to lead a respectful campaign”.Their pledge calls for derogatory, untrue, or hateful messages on social media to be publicly denounced and challenged to treat political opponents and journalists with respect, and to run an honest campaign.The SNP, Tories, Labour and Greens – all of whom have members who have experienced threats and abuse in ious forms – have all signed up.It would be a fitting tribute to Charles Kennedythis is one electoral promise they can work together and fulfil.

title: highland locations connect to 4g for the first time thanks to
story: An Tìr, An Cànan, ‘S na Daoine: EEPartnering with the Scottish Government, the Home Office and WHP Telecoms, EE has connected locations, including Tarskavaigand Glencripesdale to its high-speed G network, with Killilanand Polbaindue to be connected this summer.These sites are part of the Scottish Government’s £ million Scottish G Infill programmewhich is anticipated to deliver up to  masts to so-called ‘not spots’ in rural Scotland – including those being used by EE as part of the Emergency Services Network roll-out.Along with these sites, EE will extend G in a further  areas across the country, including to Dalwhinnie and Nairn, by the end of  as part of the Shared Rural Network Initiative, boosting connectivity in rural Scotland. The programme is run by the UK’s four mobile network operators and the UK Government to extend G coverage to % of the UK’s geography by the middle of this decade.Jane Wood, BT Group Scotland director, said: “Extending the network will offer a much-needed leline to families and businesses impacted by the ongoing pandemic, as many are working from home and keeping in touch with family and friends via digital technology.”Martyn Cheyne, WHP strategic development director, said: “WHP Telecoms is pleased to have facilitated this reliable coverage by providing robust, future-proofed infrastructure from which EE is now delivering G coverage. We welcome other operators to share this site to reduce the amount of infrastructure required in the landscape, increasing coverage and choice for everyone.”

title: barra service superhub hundreds sign
story: An Tìr, An Cànan, ‘S na DaoinePublished on Monday, the petition has already gathered well over  signatures and was created by -year-old engine cadet Eoghan MacLeod from Vatersay.: “I started the petition to get a measure of how many people agreed with me that the hub plan as it stands needs big changes for it to meet the needs of the island.“I’d heard plenty of people in person talking about their concerns so I just put together what I’d heard and put it on the petition to seewe could make these concerns more visible.“My grandmother is currently in the old folks home at St Brendan’s as she has dementia and needs to be looked after around the clock. Before there was a space available for her I was away in college and my mother had to care for my grandmother as dementia caused her to become increasingly dficult to look after.“My mother had very little free time as she had to look after my younger siblings, manage the croft, work five days a week and care for my grandmother. Replacing the old folks’ home with ‘social care flats’ would not be adequate for looking after my grandmother.”Mr MacLeod’s ‘Halt the Hub’ petition on the  degrees website is addressed to the comhairle, Scottish Government, SNP election candidate Alasdair Allan and Western Isles MP Angus MacNeil.It states: “If the comhairle is going to spend £ million on a development on Barra they shouldn’t dismiss opinions expressed by the people living on Barra. The consultation with the local community where most expressed a wish to have separate buildings for dferent local services appears to have been ignored by the decision makers in the comhairle and the Scottish Government.”One petitioner, known as Jeanne C, stated on the  degrees website: “Nothing about this ugly hub is right and there has been insufficient representation from Barra. All facilities will be smaller – with Covid distancing  We will have no care home and Eoligarry [Primary] School will be closed.“The comhairle is spending millions on decanting pupils instead of building the new school just near the old one. The comhairle and the health board can do exactly what they like with our island in the face of our expressed concerns. Lewis, by the way, is to have a new care home.”

title: uig beach clean volunteers remove two years worth of
story: An Tìr, An Cànan, ‘S na DaoineCommunity members came out in force across the course of the day with their efforts culminating in a skip-load of rubbish being cleared from Uig beach.Young and old beach buddies worked hard to remove two years’ worth of waste which had accumulated since the last event in .shortly after the beach clean, Ross Watson, the north Scotland site manager for Woodland Trust Scotland said: “It was gloriously warm and we must have had around  people take part in the clean over the course of today.“It was also a great occasion for people to catch up, so there was probably as much chatting as there was litter picking.“We filled the whole skip and had to work really hard to fit everything in. There was a huge amount of rope and all sorts of litter.“Beyond that there was general litter such as Coke bottles, beer cans, and a few face masks. The only odd thing we found was a massive oxygen tank.”Highlighting the volume of rubbish encountered during the clean, he added: “Nearly everyone who came along was from the community and they had seen this litter building up over the last two years.“The beach clean is an annual event we tend to do in April but we had to cancel last year’s so this year is basically two years’ worth including two winter storms’ worth.”When asked how much of the responsibility for the mess he believed lay with local people, he went on to say: “Some of the litter will certainly be from local industry but so much of it will be dropped from people on the island – whether locally or swept in.“The problem is not just local to here, it’s a UK-wide issue.”Addressing the challenges facing the village more broadly, Mr Watson said: “On Friday one of our contractors pulled up two trailers of fly-tipped metal down the side of one of the bridges away from the beach.“That has been years’ worth of local people dumping bikes, climbing frames and all sorts of bits and pieces. Both the Woodland Trust and the Uig Community Trust were speaking today about how we can make a bigger impact through this event, and how we can cover the whole of the community.“There is real potential for the event to be an Uig clean as a whole and not just a beach clean.“A lot of people were saying that it was the first event that they had been to in well over a year, while some of the older people hadn’t seen anyone for months.“It was a real feel-good event from that side of things.“There was a mixture of working-age parents through to retired folks.“It was great to see the kids there and have a chat with their parents. The children were appalled at the amount of litter on the beach, and we were talking about what they can do to help. Getting the message across to them about these matters at an early stage is ideal.”

title: new skye homes to be sold at a fixed
story: An Tìr, An Cànan, ‘S na Daoine revealed proposals by London-based developer Charlie Garton Jones to build  family homes in Portree on the site of the old golf course off the Struan Road.The plans,approved, will comprise  three-bedroom houses, and five four-bedroom houses, each with a garden and drive, situated on a site of around five acres in total.Mr Garton Jones lodged a planning application with Highland Council in late April this year, and hopes to provide homeowners with an ultrafast one gigabyte broadband connection free of charge for the first five years via the excess capacity the Bracken Hide Hotel will have from the nearby BT exchange.If given the green light, the scheme will be built on land next to where the developer is constructing his -cabin hotel, which is scheduled to open in April .Mr Garton Jones runs an independent estate agency specialising in the sale and rental of residential property in London, which has offices in Westminster, Nine Elms, Cha and Battersea.He also owns the Cow Shed boutique bunkhouse in Uig. report on Mr Garton Jones’ proposals has sparked a heated debate via the paper’s Facebook page over the last few days, attracting more than  comments.Although opinions dfered on the appearance of the houses, the main point of contention centred on whether the homes would be affordable and accessible to local people.Peter Brown commented: “The local community should have the final say. Personally I would think social housing should be a priority.”While Helen Grianan said: “Will these houses be £, or under  If not, they are not affordable housing for locals or key workers.”Calum J Morrison from North Uist was in favour of the scheme saying: “Sounds like a good type of thing in my opinion, the dude seems to know what he’s doing, good luck to him I say!”Annie B Campbell, meanwhile, highlighted broader issues with housing on the island, stating: “Key workers, like some NHS and teachers, are being outbid for most of the houses that come on the market in Skye.“They are not ‘officially’ homeless so do not have enough points to qualy for council housing.“Some are forced to skip between illegal short term lets. This is not simply a locals versus incomers issue.“Key workers coming to fill essential jobs on the island and local families need somewhere to live. There is a very real housing crisis.”Mr Garton Jones said the price of the houses could not be confirmed until planning permission was obtained.However, in the last few days, he took to social media to try to address worries that people on the island will be priced-out of buying the properties.“There has been a lot of focus on the larger family house we are hoping to build but  of the  houses we are building are smaller, three bedroom, houses,” he commented.Kevin McMahon simply asked: “Will there be a first refusal for locals and the children of local families ”In response, Mr Garton Jones said: “I am happy to confirm that the properties will not be sold via the Scottish ‘sealed bids offers over’ system but will be sold at a fixed price on a first-come, first-served basis.“Obviously until we have planning, we cannot sell the houses, but we have opened up a ‘waiting list’., which is the only place the houses have so far been mentioned or advertised – have emailed me to express their interest in the houses.“Many of them do, indeed, appear to be locals, although we will not be checking birth certicates as part of the sales process.”He added: “There are  houses in total, soyou would like your name added to the list, please email me via charlie@gartonjonesChisolm talked about his own chances of finding a home, questioned the effectiveness of the Highland Council in its current form, and underlined the importance of investing in smaller communities on the island.“I am living with my parents, and with my work I am fortunate to still live on Skye,” he said.“Saying that, I haven’t taken any steps to purchase a home as the prices do not justy the property, or are just too expensive.“I know people who have taken steps to purchase but were outbid either at the start or last minute.”Chisolm has worked for CalMac since  and says he has thought about moving to the Western Isles due to his poor prospects of finding a home on Skye.He said: “I have strong family connections to Lewis and Harris, and I might have the possibility of moving across as house prices haven’t been affected as much as on Skye in terms of second homes and holiday homes. However, it is now on the rise as on other neighbouring islands.”Chisolm believes a revamp of the local authority is needed to force meaningful change.“Skye is facing issues linked to the lack of investment and communications. That makes me question why are we governed by people in Inverness and not the people of Skye and the surrounding islands.“I look at the Western Isles, and I’m seeing housing developments across the islands in dferent areas with the goal of helping local people stay where they are from, sustaining school numbers — including Gaelic communities — and helping small areas grow.“That should be critical here and not just developing in Portree. Roads, housing, harbour investments are just a few aspects that link together and time is critical.”He added: “It’s very important for young people and young families to stay on the island with the support of affordable housing, whether that’s purchasing or renting.”Chisolm said he had been encouraged by responses to Iomairt an Eilein’s call to action.“Political responses ahead of the election have been very welcoming and we are grateful for the support,” he added. reported on plans to build a new -home private scheme on the outskirts of Portree.Commenting on the merits of the proposal, Chisolm said: “I welcome the new development in Portree, I’m sure many young people and families from Skye will benefit from thesethey are available at an affordable price.“That being said, I do question why we’re only developing in Portree. I can name many schools in surrounding communities that would benefit from even a half of a development like this.”Painting a stark picture of the dficulties facing townships such as Staffin, he said: “Smaller communities are missing out and our school numbers and Gaelic communities are suffering. This should be a wake-up call to our government and ‘our’ council that more housing investments in rural areas will have more of an impact and better outcomes.“We all have a right to articulate our viewpoints and opinions. Not everyone will agree but that’s what makes a community – having dferent voices for the benefit of our island.”

title: seth raises 1340 for great cause
story: A Ballymena teenager has raised more than pound for Macmillan Cancer Support after completing a half marathon at the weekend. Seth Parkis a Year  pupil at Ballymena Academy and is keen on rugby, football, golf and hockey.During lockdown he decided to keep himself fit by training for the Belfast half marathon. For  weeks Seth was pounding the roads to build his fitness and all that hard training paid idends at the weekend when he completed his run.He originally set out to raise poundbut his efforts save seen him race past that target with the current total sitting at at pound!You can help raise money for this great cause by donating directly to the fundraising page www.justgiving Seth-Park.JustGiving sends your donation straight to Macmillan Cancer Support and automatically reclaims Gt Aidyou are a UK taxpayer, so your donation is worth even more.

title: search for new nrc principal and ceo to begin shortly
story: Northern Regional College has announced that its Principal  Chief Executive, Professor Terri Scott, will be leaving the College at the end of this academic year to take up a new role as Pro Vice-Chancellor at Ulster University.Since joining the College in , Professor Scott has led the College through major transformational changes to deliver improvements, spearheading an ambitious strategy to consolidate the College’s provision across four campuses.As part of a pound million Department for the Economy funded capital building programme, new state of the art campuses are being built in both Coleraine and Ballymena.Paying tribute to Professor Scott, Barney McGahan, Chair of the College’s Governing Body, said her visionary and dynamic leadership always put students front and centre: “Terri is a very talented and committed inidual and her leaving will be a big loss to the College as her progressive leadership has been instrumental in the continued success of Northern Regional College. “She has worked in close partnership with colleagues and together they have embraced change and achieved tremendous success.“I would like to offer Terri my sincere congratulations and on behalf of the College community, I wish her the very best as she moves into her new role at Ulster University as Pro Vice-Chancellor,” he said.With an academic career spanning more than  years, Professor Scott has previously held senior leadership roles at Invest NI, Sligo Institute of Technology, Dublin City University, as well as Ulster University. In making the announcement to staff this week, Professor Scott paid tribute to her colleagues, both past and present, for embracing innovation, technology and change, and for always putting students first.A recruitment process to appoint her successor will get underway shortly.

title: 230 000 play park for grange is considered by council
story: Mid and East Antrim Borough Council have agreed a Business Case for a new pound, play and kick-about area for a rural hamlet outside Ballymena.The proposed development at The Grange would feature a range of dynamic play equipment and allow for children in the community to enjoy physical activity outdoors in a safe and inclusive environment.Following approval of the Business Case, a tender exercise for the project will commence in due course, councillors were told at this month’s Full Council meeting, which took place last night.Welcoming the progress in the new facility, Alderman William McNeilly, said: “I was delighted to propose that Council accept the Business Case for this much-needed development in the Grange area of Ballymena.OUTDOOR EXERCISE“The importance of play and outdoor exercise to the health and wellbeing of children and young people has never been more important and this new facility, when it is completed, will be an excellent addition to the area.”Councillor Brian Collins, who seconded the proposal, added: “Good quality play experiences have been shown to have a positive impact in all aspects of a child’s le and their personal development, so it is very welcome to see Council commit to investing in this proposed new facility.“I look forward to seeing how this project progresses and to the long-term benefits it will bring to the local community.”Bannside representative, Ald. Stewart McDonald also commended the plans. Posting a graphic of the proposals, he commented: “Finally, light at the end of the tunnel.”

title: minister s sweeping praise for council s campaign against litter
story: Mid and East Antrim Borough Council’s ongoing fightback against littering and waste crime has been praised by the Minister for Agriculture, Environment and Rural Affairs, Edwin Poots MLA, during a visit to the area.Council Mayor Cllr Peter Johnston, and Officers from the Waste Services Team, welcomed the Minister, who inspected a fleet of new street sweepers funded by his department.The pound, state-of-the-art equipment forms another key part of Council’s commitment to tackling littering throughout the Borough.Council has also recently teamed up with Waste Investigations Support  Enforcementfor a yearlong trial to help prosecute those who flout the rules.Enforcement Officers are working in partnership with Council Officers and have powers to issue fixed penalty noticesto anyone failing to pick up after their dog or dropping litter in the street.VALUABLE RESOURCESpeaking following the DAERA Minister’s visit, Mayor Cllr Peter Johnston, said:“I was delighted to welcome Minister Poots to Ballymena and that he was able to see for himself the new street sweepers which are another major tool in Council’s efforts to keep our local environment clean and looking its best.“As a Council we are required to provide scheduled and reactive street cleansing across the Borough.“The compact sweeper will not only support the immediate demand on the service as a result of Covid, but also help us tackle the medium to longer term increase in cleansing regime required as a result of the phased lockdown easing over the coming months.“The sweeper is a valuable resource to help us keep the streets and paths clear of litter and dog foul, and the support of the Department and Minister Poots is very welcome.“We want all those who live, work and visit Mid and East Antrim Borough in the coming weeks and months to enjoy our beautul towns, villages and countryside, and every one of us has a role to play in that.”DAERA Minister Edwin Poots MLA said: “I am pleased that my Department has been able to provide pound, of funding to purchase state-of-the-art sweeper equipment.“Here in Northern Ireland we have some of the most stunning natural landscape in the world, and the scourge of littering and dog fouling is costing us all, not just in financial terms through our public services, but especially through the harm that is caused to our precious environment for current and future generations.“It was good to see how Mid and East Antrim Borough Council is tackling these problems and sending a clear message that our local communities are worth protecting.“As we begin to see the reopening of visitor attractions across Northern Ireland over coming weeks and months, it is crucial that we all do what we can to look after the places and spaces we call home.”In addition to the new street sweeping equipment and the rollout of the WISE enforcement team, Council is also working with Keep Northern Ireland Beautul to promote environmental awareness in local schools, while additional surveying across the Borough is helping to identy areas that need extra attention.Dog fouling and littering have seen an increase throughout the Covid- pandemic, while the level of PPE such as gloves and masks, has markedly risen.

title: glenmore manor luxury lurgan family home on sale for
story: Beautul Lurgan estate has previously caught the eye of TV presenter Llewelyn-BowenExpandExpandExpandExpandExpandExpandPreviousNext" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseBeautul: Outside Glenmore Manor which is currently on the market. Credit: Mark AndersonBeautul: Outside Glenmore Manor which is currently on the market. Credit: Mark AndersonBeautul: Inside Glenmore Manor which is currently on the market. Credit: Mark AndersonBeautul: Inside Glenmore Manor which is currently on the market. Credit: Mark AndersonBeautul: Inside Glenmore Manor which is currently on the market. Credit: Mark AndersonBeautul: Inside Glenmore Manor which is currently on the market. Credit: Mark Anderson FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueBeautul: Outside Glenmore Manor which is currently on the market. Credit: Mark AndersonLauren HarteTwitterEmailMay   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailA hotel all to yourself.That was the verdict of the flamboyant interior designer and TV presenter Laurence Llewelyn-Bowen, when he first set eye on this House of the Year contender.Glenmore Manor, an th-century family manor house has ed to the market with a price tag of around £,.Currently set up as a luxury holiday let and BB, this period mansion has been lovingly restored and renovated by its proud owners, Pat and Eileen Hanna, who have worked hard to retain many of its original features while also offering some more modern conveniences.While Glenmore already boasts magnicent surroundings, the couple have added many incredible additions throughout, such as a gazebo, the Sapphire walkway and Tuscan barbecue area.The period property has a fascinating history.It was originally built in  by local solicitor Seamus Adair, who worked for a number of the local merchants and mill owners.Adair built the home on  acres and commissioned fireplaces from internationally renowned Scottish architects, the Adams brothers, who also furnished numerous palaces across Europe.The archetypal red brick exterior features classic bay windows and ornamental brickwork, in keeping with the Gothic revival movement that marked Victorian architecture.This decorative flare continues through the other features of the exterior, such as the ornate terracotta ridge tiles and decorative wooden trim. Sash windows and an elaborately designed porch complete the style.The interior features a grand entrance hall, formal staircase and a dining room with open fireplaces and two drawing rooms. Every room has views of the surrounding gardens.The large kitchen is the heart of the home and this one perfectly marries old and new worlds together.It leads to the comfortable sunroom, looking into the indoor heated swimming pool, complete with sauna, hot tub and changing facilities.The six large refined bedrooms feature traditional decor, and most offer private or en suite bathrooms.Some also have flat-screen TVs, garden views and four poster beds.Other amenities include a -personroom, a guest lounge and a patio leading to mature gardens with the covered barbecue area, a pond and meditation hut.Two separate stables have been converted into two-bedroom apartments.Indeed when it featured on the BBC’s House of the Year programme back in January , presenter Laurence Llewelyn-Bowen described Glenmore Manor as “like your own hotel, with all the facilities just for you”.Estate agent, Martin Anderson, said this stately and elegant country house represents a very rare opportunity on the market.“To put it concisely, it is nothing short of special,” he added. “Set on an extremely large site, the house is surrounded by beautully designed gardens featuring a classical water fountain, thoughtfully placed brick paved walkways, and mature trees on all sides providing complete privacy. These elements combine to make the site feel a world away from the hustle and bustle of the town.”Situated on Lough Road in Lurgan, Glenmore is an eight-minute walk from the train station and  minutes from Lord Lurgan Memorial Park.For the full listing visit propertynewsBelfast Most ReadAdrian Dunbar and top Orangeman Mervyn Gibson split over Ireland in Rory wins Wells Fargo Championship but not Credit: GettyGetty ImagesVictory: Rory McIlroy celebrates with we Erica and daughter Poppy after winning the  Wells Fargo Championship. Credit: GettyGetty Images FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueVictory: Rory McIlroy, we Erica and daughter Poppy with the trophy. Credit: GettyAllan PrestonTwitterEmailMay   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailFor Rory McIlroy and we Erica, the main order of business after celebrating his first win in  months was to comfort their eight-month old daughter Poppy.It was all too much for the tot, who found herself surrounded by cheering fans at the Wells Fargo Championship in North Carolina.Several well-known local parents told the Belfastthe public meltdown was a touching moment that seemed all too familiar.Two-time Olympic boxing bronze medallist Paddy Barnes recalled fleeing a restaurant when his daughter Eireann was two.I remember having my daughter out in Nando’s and she just squealed the place down,” he said.These two girls were coming over to me to help, but I just took her and split because everyone was looking at us.I felt really paranoid, because I felt like people were wanting us to shut up even though they were trying to help.I was just in a panic, I left with my dinner on the table. Now,my kids are crying, I wouldn’t mind as much because I’ve got more experience.”He added: “If I ever see parents with their kids crying out in public I just laugh because I can relate. There’s nothing you can do about it, it’s not the parents’ fault. Kids cry and there’s often nothing you can do about it.”On McIlroy, he said: “He’s very successful, so no doubt his baby will soon get used to it.”BBC presenting couple Connor Phillips and Holly Hamilton welcomed their son Fionn in January. Already behaving like a seasoned media professional, Connor said Fionn behaved perfectly at a recent event where his parents were working.He said: He times his little strops very well, just to make sure mummy and daddy look good. He has his moments too and can be a little a, so we do a lot of walking around the shore.Just today we were about a mile away from home and he unexpectedly woke up and he just wasn’t going back to sleep, full stop.”Asked how he deals with the stress of an upset child in public, he said: “I think back to my parentless self and think of how I might have reacted to seeing that. I might have rolled my eyes. But now as parents you go: ‘My God, the parents that have gone before me are absolute heroes’.I do think it’s the best thing in the world, though. He had a strop on the beach today and when we sat him up, he just seemed to say: ‘Thank you for that mummy and daddy’.”On McIlroy, he said: “I’m sure people think he has nannies and au pairs doing all the work. But I doubt that very much, I’m sure he’s a Holywood boy at heart looking after his wee man. I now have % empathy with parents, they’re terric, especially mums!” Comedians Diona Doherty and Sean Hegarty welcomed their daughter Winter five weeks ago. The Derry Girls and Give My Head Peace actress said feeling safe while out in public during the pandemic had been her biggest obstacle.“Today was the first day I took my daughter to the shopping centre, which was quite daunting. I know other parents who had babies during lockdown but haven’t really been anywhere for six months. That’s probably even scarier,” she said.Diona gave birth while having Covid, but now feels somewhat safer that both of them have some immunity.Any time we’re out for a walk it’s the same, it’s been cut short. Our baby has a set of lungs on her. Luckily I’m breastfeeding, so I can console her quite quickly. But you’re always planning ahead for the quickest route back.”Belfast Most ReadAdrian Dunbar and top Orangeman Mervyn Gibson split over Ireland in Rory wins Wells Fargo Championship but not everyone Credit: Kevin Scott   Belfast Kevin Scott   Belfast  FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueFirst citizen: Alliance’s Kate Nicholl, who will be the next Lord Mayor of Belfast, outside City Hall. Credit: Kevin Scott   Belfast Suzanne BreenTwitterEmailMay   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailWhen -year-old Kate Nicholl arrived in Belfast with her mother having fled Zimbabwe, she never dreamed she would end up its Lord Mayor. “My mum had £ in her purse. Without the help of the Gingerbread charity for single parents, I don’t know how we’d have coped,” she says. “We got a flat on the th floor of Riverdale House tower block in Dunmurry. It all seemed very grey. My whole world had collapsed. My parents’ marriage had broken up previously, and now we had left our home and were in a dferent country.When our belongings were shipped over, someone set fire to the boxes outside the flat. We literally lost everything, including photographs. I found it all very traumatic.”In three weeks’ time Katewill be installed as Belfast’s new Alliance Lord Mayor. The daughter of a Northern Ireland artist and a writer and ex-model from a family of anti-apartheid activists in South Africa, her story is extraordinary.“My mum and dad met at a house party in London in the s,” she says. “They were both hippies. My dad Kenneth was an artist from Holywood in Co Down. My mum, who was from Capetown, was working as a nanny.“They were both liberal and bohemian, and had found the places they’d grown up extremely restrictive. It was a whirlwind romance, but my mum Helen had to go back to South Africa as her visa was about to expire.“Back in Capetown, she wanted toto London. My grandparents, very sensibly, refused to fund a trip for their -year-old daughter to hook up with a man she’d just met. My mum had been an artists’ model and had sat for a well-known painter. She sold the portrait to buy a plane ticket to London to be with dad.”Expand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseKate Nicholl at school in Zimbabwe FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueKate Nicholl at school in ZimbabweThe couple got married and moved to Brighton. But, for some reason, they decided toto Northern Ireland where Kate’s brother Daniel and sister Ciara were born. Kenneth worked as an art teacher, and Helen secured a job in the children’s department of Robinson and Cleaver.“In  they decided they couldn’t stay here any longer,” Kate says. “The violence and sectarianism was too much. They didn’t want their children growing up in a segregated environment.“My dad started writing to dferent countries to see where he might get a job. Zimbabwe was this newly independent country that needed teachers. My parents were very excited about what Robert Mugabe stood for. It was also close to South Africa for my mum to visit her family.”The Nicholls moved to Harare before settling in the small farming town of Marondera. Kate was born there six years later. “It was a wonderful and magical childhood in so many ways,” she says.“My dad was the art teacher in the local school, and my mum the librarian. My parents were very creative and had interesting friends. There was a lot of sport — swimming and canoeing down the Zambezi.There was endless bushland to roam around. It was the most stunning landscape. I can still see the night sky with stars that seemed to go on forever. I can smell the sweet scent of the jacaranda trees in bloom.“But it was a strange environment as well. There was a lot of racism. It was very unusual for a white family like ours to have black friends. I was the only white child at school who had black classmates over to stay at the weekend. It was a totally unnatural society.”In South Africa, Kate’s grandmother had been in the Black Sash, an organisation of white women which campaigned against apartheid. They would wear black sashes to symbolise mourning for the death of democracy.Kate’s brother left Zimbabwe for university in Capetown, and her sister went to college in Belfast. Her parents’ marriage then broke up, and her father also ed to Northern Ireland.Expand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseKate with husband Fergal Sherry FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueKate with husband Fergal Sherry“It was just me and mum left,” she says. “The political situation started to get really tense. White farmers were being abducted and beaten. David Stevens, the father of a school friend, was shot dead.There were food and fuel shortages, and riots.My mum drove to town to fill her car with petrol. She waited two hours in a queue but, when she got to the front, there was none left.“She came home to find the electricity was out in another power cut. In a dark, empty house, she reached for the phone, and the lines were down. So she got into bed with a bottle of gin and decided it was time for us to leave.”When her parents had arrived in Zimbabwe, it was “a country full of political hope”, Kate says. “As a child, I wrote in my diary that Robert Mugabe was my hero. As things deteriorated, I scribbled that out and replaced him with Nelson Mandela.“Mugabe did some incredible things, but there were a lot of awful things too. Land reform was definitely needed, but he didn’t go about it the right way.There was brutality and massacres. Elections were rigged and corruption was widespread.“Land seizures destroyed the economy. Middle-class whites like us left. It was poor black Zimbabweans who were hardest hit. This beautul country, and its long-suffering people, deserved so much better.”And so in , Kate and Helen Nicholl moved into their flat in Dunmurry. “My mother is an extraordinary woman,” she says. “At  years old, with no money, no job and no friends, she was starting all over again.Expand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseKate with her son Cian FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueKate with her son Cian“Being a white African is textbook privilege. I grew up where people had horses and huge farms. But I do know what it’s like not to have money, and to worry about it. I know that le can change very quickly and you have to rely on the support and kindness of others, and being welcomed and embraced.”Kate was sent to the very middle-class Methodist College where family and financial circumstances combined to make her feel “like an outsider for years”. Eventually, she settled in.“My mum got a job in the War On Want bookshop in Botanic Avenue. It didn’t pay well, but she loved it. She built up a friendship circle with volunteers and customers. They became a second family to me.“We moved to Sunnyside Street, off the Ormeau Road, where a Georgian piano player lived next door. When she practised, we imagined ourselves to be sitting on the veranda in Marondera at dusk, listening to my sister play.”After her A-levels Kate moved in with her dad, who had cancer, to help nurse him. She then decided to go to university in London: “I still felt an outsider in Northern Ireland because of my background and accent, and I had every intention of never ing to live here again.“I decided to study anthropology because my favourite uncle in South Africa was an anthropologist, and he had the best stories. I thought I’d love London, but every time I came back to Northern Ireland to visit my family I realised that this place was home. Belfast was where I belonged.”After graduation Kate moved back here permanently. She started waitressing, and applied to do a law conversion course at Queen’s University. She also wrote to Alliance South Belfast MLA Anna Lo askingshe could do work experience in her office.Kate identied strongly with the politician from Hong Kong as someone like her who had come from abroad to make Northern Ireland her home: “She was the first person I voted for.“I respected her pro-choice stance on abortion at a time when not many people here held that position. Anna agreed to have me in for a day a week, and that turned into two days, and then it became the entire week.“A full-time job came up. I applied, got it, and forgot all about the law course. I never intended to join Alliance. I didn’t think I was suited to being a member of any political party as I was very much my own woman and I always thought it would limit me.“But the  flag protests changed my mind. They were a cynical and orchestrated move by loyalists, apparently in response to a democratic decision taken by the council, but really because Naomi Long had won the Westminster seat in East Belfast.“I saw Alliance’s office in Carrickfergus burnt down. I saw the home of a young councillor couple attacked as their baby slept inside. I decided to join the party to show solidarity with these brave and dignied people.”In  Kate was co-opted onto Belfast City Council. At the election three years later she topped the poll in the Balmoral ward. On a night out with an SDLP member in the Duke of York pub in Belfast city centre, she met her future husband, “GAA-mad accountant from Aghadrumsee in Co Fermanagh” Fergal Sherry.“I tapped this boy on the shoulder and asked him to take a photo of us on my phone. He did, and as he handed it back to me he remarked that we followed each other on Twitter. Apparently, we’d had quite a strong clash of opinion on something. We still have dferent views on certain issues, but we share similar values.“Fergal proposed in Zimbabwe in a small game reserve I’d visited on school trips. We were on top of a rock overlooking the savanna at sunset. It was perfect. I felt like I’d come full circle with my old and new lives.”The couple have a one-year-old son, Cian. “He’s had a political baptism of fire,” Kate says. “He attended his first council committee meeting at four weeks.He was breastfed in the chamber at seven weeks, and was in a BBC studio at eight weeks as we discussed the trolling I’d received for taking him into the chamber the previous week.”Kate has been chosen as a running-mate for Alliance MLA Paula Bradshaw in South Belfast in next year’s Assembly election.The party will be hoping that public exposure from being Lord Mayor will enhance her chances. It’s a fascinating constituency with the SDLP, Alliance, Sinn Fein, DUP and Greens currently each holding a seat.The SDLP will also be aiming to follow up on Claire Hanna’s spectacular Westminster win in  by having two MLAs elected. The Sinn Fein or Green seats would appear to be the most vulnerable.Kate says poverty is an issue high on her agenda. “It has grown during Covid, and there must be a long-term Government plan to tackle systemic injustice. It’s not just about handing out food parcels.If your washing-machine has broken, and your kids can’t go to school in clean clothes, a food parcel won’t help you. If you live in an empty house, it’s a bed and sofa you need, not a food parcel.“And no politician should ever have their photo taken outside a food bankthey’re not working to address the causes of inequality.”Kate says digital poverty is also an issue: “As we live more and more online, the internet should be free to everyone. Families don’t need one device per household.They need devices for all their children, they need money for electricity and data.”Her theme as Lord Mayor will be ‘Our Belfast’, she says: “We are one community and we have one city. We need to shine a light on its people and organisations, and instil a sense of collective responsibility.We must make sure the marginalised, and those who feel outsiders, know it’s their city too.For many people, Belfast is still steeped in the past and the Troubles. But for me, it’s a place of sanctuary.It’s somewhere I started my le over again. It’s a resilient, warm and welcoming city. I am delighted to call it my home, and I will be so proud to be its Lord Mayor.”Belfast Most ReadAdrian Dunbar and top Orangeman Mervyn Gibson split over Ireland in Rory wins Wells Fargo Championship Credit: Liam McBurney PAPADoug Beattie. Credit: PAPA FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueRobbie Butler and Doug Beattie appear set to go head to head for the UUP leadership.Gareth CrossTwitterEmailMay   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailRobbie Butler: Ex-firefighter viewed as one of most capable young voices of unionismAge: Current positions: UUP Chief Whip, Lagan Valley MLA.Family: Married to Belinda, with two children, daughter Robyn and son Adam.Background: Mr Butler was born in Lisburn and still lives in the area with his family.Career: After leaving school at  he trained as butcher and worked in the job for eight years before leaving to become an auxiliary prison officer in . While working in the Prison Service he dealt with high-profile loyalists like Johnny Adair and Billy Wright. He then joined the fire service in , rising to the position of watch commander before leaving to become an MLA. The UUP MLA offered to temporarilyto the fire service last yearneeded during the coronavirus pandemic.Religious views: Mr Butler has described himself as a born-again Christian, having a strong faith and has served as a deacon at Maghaberry Elim Church.Political career: Mr Butler is viewed as one of the most capable young voices in unionism and has been earmarked as a future UUP leader. He said he was he was inspired to get involved in politics out of sheer frustration at seeing the lack of political leadership in our country.He was first elected to Lisburn City Council in , before being elected to Stormont at the same time as Mr Beattie in  to represent Lagan Valley. He has twice unsuccessfully run for Westminster in the  and  General Elections.Political views: The Lagan Valley MLA has said that he considers himself neither pro-le or pro-choice, but opposed the extension of abortion legislation to NI by the UK Government. He has also expressed concern around religious protections in the event of same-sex marriage becoming legal. In  he was criticised by the DUP for representing the UUP in Dublin at a civic reception during the visit of Pope Francis.Other information: Mr Butler and his we have acted as foster parents offering emergency and respite care to children in need. He has also served as a Boys# Brigade officer.Doug Beattie: Ardent critic of NI Protocol and supporter of LGBT community here Age:  Current positions: UUP deputy leader, Upper Bann MLA. Family: Married to Margaret with two children, daughter Leigh and son Luke. Background: Born in Hampshire, England, but moved to Portadown at age  after his father was discharged from the Army. Career: A soldier by trade, Mr Beattie signed up to the Army at the age of  and served in Bosnia, Kosovo, Iraq and Afghanistan during a decorated -year military career. He has written extensively about his experiences as a soldier in a number of books, in which he spoke openly about killing an enemy during combat. He was awarded the Military Cross in recognition of his efforts during his career. Religious views: Despite a Church of Ireland background, Mr Beattie has stated he has “issues with organised religion”, but does believe in God. He has spoken about struggling with his faith following his experiences in the Army and after the sudden death of his grandson Cameron at just  months old. Political career: After an initial reluctance, Mr Beattie was persuaded to enter politics by former UUP leader Mike Nesbitt. He was elected to Armagh, Banbridge and Craigavon council in  representing Portadown. In  he was elected MLA for Upper Bann. He also unsuccessfully ran to represent Upper Bann in the House of Commons in  and . Political views: Mr Beattie is one of the more liberal UUP MLAs. He has spoken out in support of Northern Ireland’s LGBT community, appearing at Belfast Pride. He also recently introduced a motion to the Assembly calling for a ban on conversion therapy. As the UUP’s justice spokesperson he has also spoken out on matters concerning his fellow military veterans, legacy issues and policing. Mr Beattie has also been an ardent critic of the post-Brexit Northern Ireland Protocol. Other information: In his early years in the Army he was stationed in Germany and served as guard at the notorious Spandau Prison.Belfast Most ReadAdrian Dunbar and top Orangeman Mervyn Gibson split title: nine year old dubai dj scratches her way to fame in world contest
story: Michelle Rasul in the lobby of her apartment building in Dubai, United Arab Emirates  FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueMichelle Rasul in the lobby of her apartment building in Dubai, United Arab Emirates By Malak Harb, Associated PressMay   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailA nine-year-old girl who lives in Dubai is scratching her way to the top as a DJ in world competitions.Michelle Rasul was already spinning turntables, scratching hip-hop records and making the beats drop four years ago, when she was just learning how to read and write.Four years later, she is one of the world’s top DJs and competed in this year’s global championship.At her home in the skyscraper-studded city of Dubai, the turntable whiz from Azerbaijan nodded her baseball cap-adorned head to the beat and showed off her skills scratching, cutting and fading."data-srcset"https:www.belfasttelegraph news world-news cac .ece AUTOCROP w bpanews_dcd-cea-e-aa-deece_embedded w,https:www.belfasttelegraph news world-news cac .ece AUTOCROP w bpanews_dcd-cea-e-aa-deece_embedded w" data-sizes"auto"  "Expand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeClose"data-srcset"https:www.belfasttelegraph news world-news cac .ece AUTOCROP w bpanews_dcd-cea-e-aa-deece_embedded w,https:www.belfasttelegraph news world-news cac .ece AUTOCROP w bpanews_dcd-cea-e-aa-deece_embedded w" data-sizes"auto"  "Michelle Rasul enjoys scratching her turntable in the lobby of her apartment building in Dubai AP PA Images FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueMichelle Rasul enjoys scratching her turntable in the lobby of her apartment building in Dubai Her tiny fingers flew across the turntable as she created a sizzling landscape of electric audio effects and recalled how she got her start as a child turntable celebrity – which, in fact, was not all that long ago.“I looked at my dad while he was practising DJ-ing and I saw him and was like, ‘Wow, is he doing magic or something  He’s a real magician, bro!’” Michelle told the Associated Press, bubbling with enthusiasm.“When I turned five, on my birthday, I told him, ‘Dad, I want to be a world famous DJ. I’m going to start practising’.”As though recounting a decades-long career, she grinned and added: “And the rest is history.”"data-srcset"https:www.belfasttelegraph news world-news e .ece AUTOCROP w bpanews_dcd-cea-e-aa-deece_embedded w,https:www.belfasttelegraph news world-news e .ece AUTOCROP w bpanews_dcd-cea-e-aa-deece_embedded w" data-sizes"auto"  "Expand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeClose"data-srcset"https:www.belfasttelegraph news world-news e .ece AUTOCROP w bpanews_dcd-cea-e-aa-deece_embedded w,https:www.belfasttelegraph news world-news e .ece AUTOCROP w bpanews_dcd-cea-e-aa-deece_embedded w" data-sizes"auto"  "Michelle Rasul chases a friend’s dog at a park near her house AP PA Images FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueMichelle Rasul chases a friend’s dog at a park near her house Michelle, the youngest-ever contestant in the DMC World DJ Championship, ranked th out of  DJ stars from around the world in the Portablist category this year, the global portable scratch competition.The  competition was held online due to the coronavirus pandemic.Although she did not advance to the next round this time, she is determined to beat her father, Vag “DJ Shock” Rasulov, a professional who taught her the tricks of the trade and was ninth this year, in next year’s competition.“I love competing in battles, I just love DJ-ing,” she said.“It’s my passion.”"data-srcset"https:www.belfasttelegraph news world-news fd .ece AUTOCROP w bpanews_dcd-cea-e-aa-deece_embedded w,https:www.belfasttelegraph news world-news fd .ece AUTOCROP w bpanews_dcd-cea-e-aa-deece_embedded w" data-sizes"auto"  "Expand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeClose"data-srcset"https:www.belfasttelegraph news world-news fd .ece AUTOCROP w bpanews_dcd-cea-e-aa-deece_embedded w,https:www.belfasttelegraph news world-news fd .ece AUTOCROP w bpanews_dcd-cea-e-aa-deece_embedded w" data-sizes"auto"  "Michelle Rasul scratching her turntable AP PA Images FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueMichelle Rasul scratching her turntable Turntabling, which burst on to the music scene from hip-hop artists in the late s, can look like a basic act – taking a record, putting the needle down and sliding it back and forth with one’s fingertips.But for the wizards, it is an art form, involving spontaneous sound mixing and advanced techniques like quick, rhythmic scratches and “crabs”, rubbing the record under the needle.From the moment her parents gave her a mini DJ starter kit, they recognised her extraordinary abilities.Even as a baby, she was fascinated and would punch all the buttons on her father’s equipment.“She just catches things so fast,” said her mother Sadia Rasulova, a former violinist who also encouraged Michelle’s love of music."data-srcset"https:www.belfasttelegraph news world-news f .ece AUTOCROP w bpanews_dcd-cea-e-aa-deece_embedded w,https:www.belfasttelegraph news world-news f .ece AUTOCROP w bpanews_dcd-cea-e-aa-deece_embedded w" data-sizes"auto"  "Expand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close realised that she’s a star, that she’s really talented.”When her peers were listening to nursery rhymes, or as she put it, “Baby Shark stuff or ABC songs”, Michelle said she was hooked on rap legends such as Tupac Shakur, Chuck D, Jay-Z, the Notorious B.I.G. and Michael Jackson, who remains her favourite.Her parents started posting footage of her scratching online, and Michelle’s popularity exploded.Her Instagram account and persona as the self-described “youngest DJ in the world” has racked up , followers.Online messages from aspiring DJs aged six to  poured in from around the globe, she said."data-srcset"https:www.belfasttelegraph news world-news ccb .ece AUTOCROP w bpanews_dcd-cea-e-aa-deece_embedded w,https:www.belfasttelegraph news world-news ccb .ece AUTOCROP w bpanews_dcd-cea-e-aa-deece_embedded w,https:www.belfasttelegraph news world-news ccb .ece AUTOCROP w bpanews_dcd-cea-e-aa-deece_embedded w" data-sizes"auto"  "Michelle Rasul jumps around in the lobby of her apartment AP PA Images FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueMichelle Rasul jumps around in the lobby of her apartment Michelle’s feed is populated with posts of her breakdancing and scratching furiously alongside her sunglasses-sporting father, spinning hip-hop and techno tunes live for her listeners, strumming the bass in her free time and playing at events such as Dubai’s recent food festival.Before the pandemic put big gatherings on hold, Michelle performed regularly at weddings, parties and music festivals across the city.While the rest of the world is focused on her accomplishments as a DJ star, Michelle is busy bouncing through le, attending online school, skateboarding, reading and hanging out with friends and dogs at her neighbourhood park.But her heart is always in her turntabling.“I can’t imagine my le without music,” she said.“Like from the start, from the very beginning, when I was really little.”PAMost ReadAdrian Dunbar and top The owner of a Derry cafe will be delivering free turkey dinners with all the trimmings to the needy on Christmas Day.Paula Monk has been running Peggy’s Kitchenin The Old Library Trustin Creggans Central Drive for over a year.Last Christmas she and her business partner Adam Nabaz delivered over  free Christmas dinners and this year they will be doing it all over again.The need in the community this year is greater than ever because of the coronavirus, said Ms Monk. So Ill be in the kitchen prepping on Christmas Eve and then the dinner will be cooked and delivered on Christmas Day for anyone who’s alone or in need of one.Last year we actually had some spare meals left over so I went and delivered them up to the Fire Station, which was the highlight of my Christmas, she said.Paula has been provided with the names of people in the local community who would benefit from the scheme by the Operation Snowball at the OLT and staff at the Long Tower Youth Club.This service is free of charge of course, soyou or someone you know needs help this Christmas please send me a message to the Peggys Kitchen Facebook page,continued Ms Monk. googletag.cmd.push Last year we covered the cost of it ourselves, apart from the desserts, but this year Foyle Fruit have kindly offered to donate the potatoes and vegetables and we have also had donations of containers and cups. All donations are welcome andanyone wishes to help our efforts that help would be much appreciated.Ms Monk has enlisted the help of two delivery drivers to take the food to the Bogside, Brandywell and Creggan areas of the city.Like all cafes, Peggys Kitchen is closed at the moment due to current restrictions.Its sad that we cant open because we really miss our customers like the Over s Club that used to meet here every Wednesday and for a lot of them it was their only source of interaction but the safety of everyone needs to come first, said Ms Monk. googletag.cmd.push We cant wait to reopen again but until then please keep safe.      --If you have a story or want to send a photo or video to us please contact the Derry Now editorial team on    for Derry City stories Or    for County Derry stories. Mayo official Jerome Henry has been appointed to take charge of Derrys opening NFL game. Rory Gallaghers side begin their league campaign next Saturdayagainst Longford at Glennon Brothers Pearse Park. Derry will then face Fermanaghand Cavan in Kingspan Breffni Park in their remaining Division  North games. Tipperary, Wicklow, Limerick and Offaly are the teams in Division  South. The top two from each section will play in the Division  promotions semi-finals, with the bottom two from each section battling it out in the avoid the drop to Division . The number of Covid- cases in County Derry has remained around the same level for the previous  days, the latest figures have shown. Only three of the countys postal areas recorded an increase in cases, with Derry Citys BT  BT areas showing the highest increases, with BT recording the highest rate per , of population throughout Northern Ireland. The number of tests administered fell by .%.  Overall, County Derrys rate per , of populationremains over double the NI figure , while a further  cases resulted in an increase of .% in positive cases from last week. googletag.cmd.push .% of all tests carried out over the last seven days were positive, an increase of .% on the previous week, while BTs % figure was the highest in the county. Portstewart, despite carrying out  tests, recorded no positive cases, while Colerainescases rose from  to  over the last seven days.  There was one Covid-related death recorded in the countys three local government districts over the last week, coming in Causeway Coast and Glens. None were recorded in Mid Ulster or Derry City and Strabane. Altnagelvin Hospital currently has  Covid patients, with Antrim Area treating . googletag.cmd.push , first doses of the vaccine have now been administered, representing .% of the NI population, while , have received their second dose, leaving .% of the population fully vaccinated against the virus. Meanwhile, Health Minister Robin Swann has announced arrangements to facilitate increased visiting in health and social care settings will come into force on Friday May .  The guidelines, spread over two documents, offer bespoke advice depending on the category of care setting involved. “I fully recognise the importance of visiting for those who are receiving care. I hope this guidance will be widely welcomed, said Mr Swann. “It is also important to remember that the threat from COVID- remains very real. Everyone has a vital role to play when it comes to safe visiting. That includes social distancing, hand hygiene and not visitingyou are feeling unwell yourself.      Visiting was only ever restricted because it was absolutely necessary to do so to protect patients and residents from the risk of transmission of SARS-CoV- virus and subsequent development of COVID- infection. Given the progress that has been made against the virus, the time is now right to take steps to carefully re-introduce visiting. I welcome the work completed to draw up these updated guidance documents and hope that by implementing them we will take another step along the road to recovery.”   --If you have a story or want to send a photo or video to us please contact the Derry Now editorial team on    for Derry City stories Or    for County Derry stories. Shiels delivered the League Cup, their last piece of silverware. His son Dean was again part of the success in a - victory over Cobh Ramblers at the Brandywell. It wasnt enough to save his job. His tenure as manager coincided with the death of Derry skipper and club legend Ryan McBride, something that affected him badly. Kenny read out an emotional poem, In Your Absence, at Ryans funeral, which was greeted with a rapturous applause. “We lost eight players in the August of the third year,” Kenny states. “They wanted away some of them. I made a couple of bad signings, which you do.” Part of him wanted to stay, but he sensed an element of the dressing room wasnt in his corner. “I felt it,” he admits. “Ive always prided myself in having a good dynamic in the dressing room. In the professional game, you have a term where you are doing well and a term when it is not so good.” The mutual decision saw them part ways. He knows that bad times are inevitable. It could happen in his current role. “It happens to everybody,” Kenny admits. *** Carrick Rangers win over Glentoran was a seismic result in its own right, but one thing pleased Kenny Shiels more, watching his side pass them off the pitch. “I had a style of play and I still have it,” Kenny now states. “We got on the ball and we play, with our passing style and patterns.” He enjoys the tactical side of the game, but taking charge of Northern Ireland women was a dferent preposition. Transforming them into the first side to qualy for the European Championships is top of the tree in a footballing career that is glittered with success. “If you dig deep into it,” Kenny explains. “These girls hadnt won a match in almost four years, prior to us coming in.” Magherafelts Simone Magilland Rebecca Hollowayare the sole professional players. Sarah McFadden, also from Magherafelt, plays part-time with Durham. The rest are amateur. The fallow spell had corroded any bleak sign of confidence. Standing in Greenmount College, with felt tip pen in hand, their new manager steered his sides mentality in a very definite direction. Two words were etched onto the flip-chart...trust and integrity. His two cornerstones. “You cant have one without the other and I told them they were the focal points in their time with me,” Shiels said. “Thats what we work off, in everything we do. They are related to team spirit and teamwork in any sport.” Even now, sitting on his sofa, reciting that first meeting, his eyes are dancing. You can see how he was able to hold a team in the palm of his hand. It wasnt about just trusting each other. The squad needed to believe in the staff, the process of improvement. But, most of all, they had to trust themselves. “You cant get better without trust,” he told them. “The best and most important relationship you can have anywhere in the world, with any person...is the relationship with yourself. “If you dont trust and believe in yourself, and you havent got a strong relationship with yourself, youll never achieve anything in your le.” Shiels had to pick them off the canvas. Unlike a club environment, there is no transfer market. It was a case of building a team from scratch. In the opposite corner, they were pitting themselves against players from Barcelona and Lyon, stars from the top English clubs, Manchester City, Arsenal and Cha. “Wales, who we eliminated over two games, they have a full team, maybe  of them, playing in the Womens Super League,” Shiels adds. Their resolve was tested by two - defeats by former European and World Champions Norway, either side of their two draws with Wales. “My full backs go forward, we play an attacking game,” Shiels points out. “Norway beat us - in Belfast, but in the second half, we had the same or more possession than them and it was a great learning curve.” Northern Ireland finished the group with four wins, twice each against Belarus and the Faroe Islands to book their play-off with Ukraine. Simone Magill and Rachel Furness celebrate Northern Irelands - win over Belarus in the Dinamo National Olympic Stadium, Minsk.As part of the preparations, Shiels accepted an approach to play England in St Georges Park, something seen as a gamble of sorts. After rebuilding the confidence, a hiding, by more than six goals, couldve set them back. Trailing - after facing a stf breeze, Northern Ireland played much better in the second-half but went down - in the end, but Shiels was happy. It was another learning curve. Going into the first leg of the play-off, Shiels had four players out with cruciate ligament injuries, Lauren Wade had an ankle injury and goalscorer Rachel Furness hobbled off minutes with a broken ankle. A Magill goal saw Shiels side come home with a - win from Ukraine before winning - in the second leg, to book their place in the finals. “They have  million of a population and have recently been in the finals,” he said of Ukraines pedigree. Of the  teams in next summers finals, ranked by coefficient, only Scotland from the top  ranked teams have failed to qualy. Northern Ireland are ranked th. “We are in with the big shots now,” Shiels points out. The rankings are based on results, discipline, performances, essentially anything quantiable. “The coefficient we got in the fth year, was twice as much as the other four years combined. That is massive.” He has come a long way from dribbling through the tackles on the tarmac of Beagh Primary School, but Shiels is still leading the way.
